Senate President Rodrigo Pacheco noted he was in 'permanent contact' with the Governor of the Federal District, Ibaneis Rocha, who is "concentrating the efforts of the entire police apparatus in order to control the situation." 

World leaders have condemned the violence and offered their support to Lula. Spain's Pedro Sánchez expressed his "full support to President Lula and to the institutions that were freely and democratically chosen by the Brazilian people," while Chile's Gabriel Boric labeled the events a "cowardly and vile attack on democracy." Colombia's Gustavo Petro remarked, "Fascism decides to conduct a coup." 

Lula defeated army captain Bolsonaro in a contentious election on October 30, the results of which many protesters dispute, claiming they were fraudulent. One protester, identified as Lima, told Agence France-Presse: "We need to re-establish order after this fraudulent election." Bolsonaro had previously made unfounded allegations about the electronic voting system and did not formally concede defeat. 

On the eve of Lula's inauguration on January 1, Bolsonaro left Brazil for Florida, where he remains; he is a staunch ally of Donald Trump. His supporters had previously camped outside military barracks to rally support for a potential military coup. On December 13, protests escalated as demonstrators attempted to storm police headquarters, setting buses and cars on fire. The Associated Press suggested that Congress and the Supreme Court may have been less secure on a Sunday, making them more vulnerable to attack. 

The January 6, 2021 assault on the US Capitol saw supporters of Donald Trump attempt to disrupt the certification of Joe Biden's election victory. In August, Thomas Shannon, the US ambassador to Brazil under Barack Obama, remarked to The Guardian that Bolsonaro's team had closely studied the January 6 incident to understand why an incumbent president failed to overturn election results.

title: 118th United States Congress convenes; House of Representatives adjourns without electing Speaker for first time in 100 years
content:
**Friday, January 6, 2023**

The United States Congress convened on Tuesday to begin its 118th session. Vice President Kamala Harris, serving as the ex officio President of the Senate, swore in new and reelected Senators in the Senate chamber shortly after noon EST (17:00 UTC).

The Republican-majority House of Representatives is conducting a roll call election for Speaker. In the first ballot on Tuesday, all 212 House Democrats voted for their leader, Representative Hakeem Jeffries, while 203 House Republicans supported their leader, Representative Kevin McCarthy. Additionally, 19 Republicans cast their votes for other candidates. As no candidate achieved the required 218-vote majority, the House moved to a second ballot for the first time since 1923.

The second ballot reflected the same totals for Jeffries and McCarthy, but the 19 Republicans who opposed McCarthy voted as a bloc for Representative Jim Jordan, despite his withdrawal from the race and endorsement of McCarthy. A third ballot yielded 212 votes for Jeffries, 202 for McCarthy, and 20 for Jordan. At approximately 5:29 PM EST (22:29 UTC), the House adjourned until noon EST (17:00 UTC) on Wednesday.

As of Thursday, the House has still not elected a Speaker after six ballots. Once the election concludes, the winning candidate will swear in the members-elect and oversee the House's adoption of session rules.

In the Democratic-majority Senate, Harris swore in the senior Senator from Washington State, Patty Murray, as President pro tempore. Murray is the first woman to hold this position and is now third in the presidential line of succession. The Senate began adopting its rules on Tuesday afternoon.

Senators serve staggered six-year terms, resulting in approximately one-third of the 100 Senate seats up for election every two years. Currently, there are 51 Democrats (including three independents who caucus with them) and 49 Republicans in the Senate. In contrast, Representatives serve two-year terms, meaning all House seats are contested in every federal election; there are currently 222 Republicans, 212 Democrats, and one vacancy in the House.

title: Japanese military helicopter goes down at sea, 10 missing
content:
**Tuesday, April 11, 2023**

A Japanese military helicopter crashed off the coast of Miyako Island in the East China Sea on Thursday, with all 10 individuals on board reported missing. The aircraft, a UH-60JA variant of the Black Hawk, was operated by the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force (JGSDF). It disappeared from Japanese radar between Miyako Island and Irabu Island just 10 minutes after taking off.

On Friday morning, the Japan Coast Guard discovered a door, a rotor blade, and an unused lifeboat bearing markings consistent with the missing helicopter during their search operations. 

Defense Minister Yasukazu Hamada stated, "We will do our utmost to rescue the 10 people who are still missing while continuing to gather information on the extent of the damage."

Among those on board were two pilots, two mechanics, and six passengers, including Lieutenant General Yuichi Sakamoto, a senior JGSDF commander overseeing the 8th Division. The JGSDF reported that the helicopter had passed a safety inspection in March.

title: US House of Representatives rejects resolution to order troop withdrawal from Syria
content:
**Saturday, March 11, 2023**

On Wednesday, the US House of Representatives voted 321–103 to reject a resolution that would have required the president to withdraw approximately 900 US troops stationed in Syria. The resolution was introduced by Republican Representative Matt Gaetz on February 21. 

Gaetz expressed, "I do not believe what stands between a caliphate and not a caliphate are the 900 Americans who have been sent to this hellscape with no definition of victory." The Associated Press reported that a US operation in Syria just four days prior resulted in the wounding of four US servicemembers and the elimination of a senior Islamic State leader. 

On his congressional website, Gaetz contended, "Congress has never authorized kinetic participation of U.S. Armed Forces in Syria." 

Opposing the resolution, Representative Michael McCaul, chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, warned that withdrawing forces might lead to a resurgence of the Islamic State. "The withdrawal of this legal, authorized US troop deployment must be based on the total defeat of ISIS," he added. 

Representative Gregory Meeks, the top Democrat on the Foreign Affairs Committee, remarked, "This measure forces a premature end to our mission at a critical time for our efforts," though he also voiced concerns regarding an indefinite US presence in Syria.

Since September 2014, the US has conducted military operations in Syria against the Islamic State as part of Operation Inherent Resolve. These operations have been justified under the Authorization for Use of Military Force of 2001 (AUMF) and the 2002 Authorization for Use of Military Force Against Iraq Resolution. The 2001 AUMF, the longest actively used AUMF in US history, was initially passed to authorize military action in the aftermath of the September 11 attacks, while the 2002 AUMF first authorized the Iraq War.

According to a Congressional Research Service report, congressional efforts to establish a new authorization for anti-Islamic State operations began in late 2014. On June 17, 2021, the House passed H.R.256, which aimed to repeal the 2002 AUMF. At that time, Meeks stated, "Repeal is crucial because the executive branch has a history of stretching the 2002 AUMF's legal authority." However, the bill did not advance in the Senate.

On Wednesday, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 13–8 in favor of repealing the 2002 AUMF as well as a 1991 AUMF, setting the stage for a vote before the full Senate.

title: Waymo announces expansion of autonomous taxi coverage in Arizona, San Francisco
content:
**Thursday, May 11, 2023**

On May 4, Waymo, the US autonomous vehicle company, announced on its blog that Waymo One, its robotaxi service, would nearly double its coverage in the Phoenix, Arizona area. The expansion includes a new stop at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, allowing up to four passengers in each robotaxi. Additionally, the company plans to extend its services across the entire San Francisco peninsula in California.

Chief Product Officer Saswat Panigrahi expressed confidence in the service, stating, "We are feeling tremendous wind at our backs." He revealed that Waymo is currently facilitating 10,000 fully autonomous rides for public passengers each week, with expectations to grow that number to 100,000 by next summer. "I want to clarify that these are external riders; this does not include rides provided to our own employees," Panigrahi added.

Panigrahi described the Phoenix area as the "largest contiguous AV area in the world," with Waymo set to extend its operations to a 180-square mile (466 square kilometer) region that includes the resort town of Scottsdale, complementing its existing coverage of Phoenix and the East Valley’s Chandler, Gilbert, Mesa, and Tempe.

In San Francisco, Waymo plans to offer rides for free, 24/7, except in neighborhoods like Fisherman's Wharf and North Beach, which will only accommodate staff and select volunteers known as Trusted Testers. The company has requested permission from the California Public Utilities Commission to institute fees in San Francisco, which, if approved, would make it the first city to host robotaxi services from two companies, as General Motors-owned Cruise has been charging for rides in certain areas since June.

However, Waymo One vehicles have faced challenges in San Francisco, with the Associated Press reporting instances like sudden stops on streets—one incident involved five robotaxis halting simultaneously due to fog and obstructed traffic. Other issues reported include interference with emergency services and rear-end collisions involving buses. Local regulators have criticized Waymo's expansion as "unreasonable" in a letter to the Commission.

In response, Panigrahi acknowledged these challenges: "Now, as part of deploying a fully autonomous vehicle, there are clearly additional learnings that we're responding to, and we will place safety at the forefront, first and foremost." He emphasized that Waymo One is "continuously improving."

Phoenix's Street Transportation Department declined to comment to Wikinews last Thursday regarding measures taken to ensure the safety of the robotaxis, stating that it is "not the regulating agency for autonomous vehicles."

Waymo, a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc. based in Mountain View, California, began as Google's secret autonomous vehicle project over a decade ago. The company started testing in Phoenix in 2017 and began offering paid rides in late 2020 over an area of approximately 60 square miles (155 square kilometers).

title: Powerful earthquake rocks Vanuatu archipelago
content:
**Friday, January 13, 2023**

A powerful earthquake, likely measuring 7.0 on the Richter scale, struck the Oceanian nation of Vanuatu at 11:30 PM VUT on Saturday (10:30 UTC on Sunday). Fortunately, there have been no reports of casualties.

Following the quake, the United States Geological Survey issued a tsunami warning for "waves reaching 0.3 to one meter [3.9 feet] above the tide level" along the coasts of Vanuatu, New Caledonia, and the Solomon Islands. However, the warning was quickly lifted after it became clear that no tsunami would occur.

The French Embassy in Port Vila also posted a statement on its Facebook page advising residents to "stay away from the coasts until the alert is lifted." 

Kayson Pore, a 22-year-old college student living on Vanuatu's largest island, Espiritu Santo, shared his experience with Agence France-Presse: "We were right on the sea, looking for crabs on the coast when the quake hit. It was very huge. We ran for our lives and then headed to our homes. People were moving to higher ground" to escape a potential tsunami.

Some residents took to social media to report damaged items. Pore noted that the quake had knocked over and shattered cups in his kitchen but observed no significant damage to homes in his town of Hog Harbour, which has a population of about 1,000.

The New Zealand National Emergency Management Agency stated they did not anticipate any tsunamis affecting their coast.

The Vanuatuan islands are situated along the convergent boundary of the Australian and Pacific tectonic plates, part of the Ring of Fire, an area known for frequent seismic activity.

In November, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake struck the Solomon Islands but did not result in serious casualties or destruction. In contrast, a devastating magnitude 7.5 earthquake in 2018 on the island of Sulawesi in Indonesia resulted in 4,300 fatalities or missing persons.

According to last year's WorldRiskReport, which evaluates the disaster risk in 193 countries, Vanuatu was ranked 49th on its WorldRiskIndex.

title: Russian travel writer Viktor Pinchuk recounts Oceania expedition in Simferopol, Crimea
content:
**Monday, March 13, 2023**

On March 6, Russian Wikinews attended a lecture by travel writer Viktor Pinchuk in Simferopol, Crimea, focusing on his 2018–2019 voyage to Oceania. 

The event was held at the Scientific Library of Crimean Federal University and featured introductory remarks from Library Director Natalya Kadukha and Gennady Samokhin, chairman of the Crimean branch of the Russian Geographical Society (RGO). 

Pinchuk shared that he authored eighteen articles for Russian Wikipedia and eight textbooks for Russian Wikibooks following his expedition, including one titled "Two Months of Wandering and 14 Days Behind Bars." 

In response to audience questions, Pinchuk emphasized, "Travelers didn't die out hundreds of years ago; they simply got lost among the countless tourists." 

A selection of photographs featured in the book includes images from Vanuatu, Tonga, and Samoa.

title: Sydney, Australia woman who "spontaneously" murdered boyfriend in "fatal explosion of emotion" sentenced
content:
**Monday, March 13, 2023**

On Friday, Jackline Sabana Bona Musa, a woman from Sydney, Australia, was sentenced to 20 years in prison, including time served, for fatally crushing her boyfriend during a confrontation in 2020. She will be eligible for parole in 2034.

Justice Richard Button, who presided over the sentencing, characterized the act as "spontaneous and not premeditated," while acknowledging it as a "grave example of an extremely serious offense." He stated, "The intention to inflict serious harm existed for only a matter of seconds. One cannot be satisfied of an intention to kill."

However, he emphasized the severity of the act: "The life of a fellow human being was violently extinguished in a place where he was entitled to feel safe. His final moments were short but terrifying, and he surely died in great pain. This was a deeply self-centered act of violence."

Justice Button reflected on Musa's challenging early life, referring to it as "grossly deprived and traumatic." He recounted her childhood in Sudan, where she faced poverty, the early death of her father, and the struggles of her mother to care for a large family amidst difficult circumstances. He noted, "I accept that she suffered many traumatic and horrific experiences over the years."

Musa arrived in Australia as a refugee in 2004, having lost many family members to war and poverty. At that time, she was dealing with post-traumatic stress disorder and fluctuating anxiety and depression. Despite her past, Button acknowledged that Musa had maintained consistent employment, cared for her four children and aging mother, and completely abstained from drugs and alcohol.

In his concluding remarks, Justice Button described the case as a tragedy from multiple perspectives: "A life was taken simply because a fellow human being was exercising autonomy in romantic matters […] The violence inflicted upon him, whereby he was crushed to death, is deplorable. There is no remorse on the part of the offender, even now. However, after a life of great deprivation, she managed to make a fresh start in this country, which deserves recognition."

He expressed hope for Musa's future, stating, "Many years from now, the offender has a good chance of becoming a valued member of the community again."

title: Jury finds former US President Trump liable in defamation, sexual abuse case
content:
**Sunday, May 14, 2023**

After less than three hours of deliberation, a federal jury in Manhattan found former U.S. President Donald Trump liable for sexual abuse and defamation against plaintiff E. Jean Carroll. The jury, consisting of six men and three women, awarded Carroll $5 million—approximately $2 million for sexual abuse and $3 million for defamation. However, the jury did not find Trump liable for rape.

Trump responded to the verdict on his Truth Social app, calling it "A DISGRACE," and indicated his intention to appeal during an interview with Fox News Digital.

While visiting his properties in Scotland and Ireland, Trump claimed he would participate in the trial's final stages but did not accept the judge's offer to submit a motion by May 7 to reopen the case and testify.

In his now-public video deposition, Trump stated he had "absolutely no idea who this woman [Carroll] is," and described her as "not my type." Furthermore, he mistakenly identified her as his second wife, Marla Maples, when shown a group photo including both women.

Trump reiterated remarks from the Access Hollywood tape, suggesting he could grab women by their genitals because he was "a star," later adding, "Unfortunately or fortunately."

Carroll, a former advice columnist for Elle, testified for three days. When defense attorney Joe Tacopina inquired why she did not scream during the alleged assault, she responded: "One of the reasons women don't come forward is because they're always asked, 'Why didn't you scream?' Some women scream. Some women don't. It keeps women silent." 

Tacopina also questioned Carroll about why she did not file a police report in spring 1996; she explained that she felt too "ashamed." She shared: "I was born in 1943. I'm a member of the silent generation. Women like me were taught to keep our chins up and not complain. I would never call the police about something I am ashamed of."

Two friends testified that Carroll had informed them of the alleged assault shortly after it occurred. Carroll stated that following the incident, she was unable to engage in sexual relationships or even smile at men she found attractive.

"I was never going to talk about what Donald Trump did," Carroll said, adding that she published a memoir in 2019 accusing him, inspired by the #MeToo movement. Trump began denying the encounter and insisted that Carroll was "not my type," which she claimed "shattered my reputation," ultimately leading to her dismissal from Elle months later.

Due to the expiration of the statute of limitations, criminal charges against Trump are not possible. Carroll's lawsuit against Trump was filed under the 2022 Adult Survivors Act, which permitted New Yorkers a one-year window to sue individuals accused of sexual crimes.

title: Australian broadcaster projects Liberal win in Ryde district, New South Wales, two weeks after state election
content:
**Thursday, April 13, 2023**

On Friday, Antony Green, an analyst for Australia's ABC News, projected that the Liberal Party's Jordan Lane would win the state electorate of Ryde, New South Wales. By Saturday, Lane was leading by just 50 votes out of a total of 50,800, with both he and Labor candidate Lyndal Howison receiving 50% of the vote as postal ballots were being counted. Despite being classified as a safe seat by The Guardian, Ryde experienced a significant 8.9% swing against the Liberal Party.

Lane, a former mayor of the City of Ryde, expressed his commitment to the community in a statement: "I love Ryde and will continue to fight every day to deliver on our positive vision for our community and its future. I look forward to working hard for everyone in Ryde, no matter who they voted for."

In response, Howison remarked, "Ryde is my home, and regardless of the final result, I'll always fight for what's best for our community." The lead had fluctuated between Lane and Howison since the election on March 25. Prior to the current projections, Howison acknowledged that the situation was "not looking good for the Labor campaign," but asserted that her party would wait for more votes to be counted before making any final decisions.

Labor secured 45 seats but fell two short of achieving a majority government. Both The Guardian and the Australian Associated Press suggest that this outcome may prompt newly elected Premier Chris Minns to enter negotiations with the crossbench, which is made up of nine independents and three Greens.

In the 2019 election, Liberal Victor Dominello won Ryde by an 18% margin, although that contest also saw a 2.6% swing toward Labor. Dominello, who had served as the Member for Ryde since 2008, retired before this election, and Lane described him as "a close friend and a mentor."

title: New American Psychological Association guidelines: Parents should advise teenagers on social media use, impose restrictions
content:
**Friday, May 12, 2023**

On Tuesday, the American Psychological Association (APA) released recommendations urging parents to offer guidance and training to teenagers on responsible social media usage, including limitations on screen time. 

The APA presented 10 suggestions for ensuring safe social media practices among adolescents. The report emphasized the importance of parents educating their teenagers about social media literacy and providing support for their psychological development before they engage with these platforms.

Additionally, the advisory highlighted a lack of research on the impact of social media use among diverse youth populations, including those who are racially, ethnically, sexually, or gender diverse, as well as youth from various socioeconomic backgrounds or those with chronic developmental or health issues. It called for increased funding for further studies in this area.

A panel of experts reviewed existing research on social media use to formulate these recommendations. APA CEO Dr. Arthur C. Evans, Jr. remarked, "We hope these recommendations will be helpful as we all try to keep pace with the rapidly shifting social media ecosystem." 

Dr. Thema Bryant, the Association's President, added, "Social media is neither inherently harmful nor beneficial to our youth."

title: New study analyzes the varying levels of protection offered by COVID-19 vaccines
content:
**Revised Version:**

**Friday, May 12, 2023**

A study conducted by researchers at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) has found that COVID-19 vaccines provide varying levels of protection during the six months following vaccination. The findings were published in the journal *Scientific Reports* on Tuesday.

The BOOST study (Building Optimal Antibodies Study) involved 498 participants aged 18 to 88. Researchers assessed the levels of COVID-19 neutralizing antibodies in individuals who received the Pfizer, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson vaccines.

One month after vaccination, volunteers who received the Pfizer vaccine exhibited an antibody response 21 times higher than those who received the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. Meanwhile, the Moderna group showed an antibody response 51 times greater than that of the Johnson & Johnson group. However, six months later, the Johnson & Johnson recipients demonstrated higher antibody levels than the Pfizer group, matching the levels found in the Moderna group.

Dr. Aric Prather from the UCSF Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, affiliated with the Weill Institute for Neurosciences, emphasized this observation, stating, "While the mechanism for this increase is unknown, other smaller studies have suggested this trend, leading us to believe there are robust phenomena not specific to our sample."

All three vaccines were found to be effective; however, the study also examined factors that could diminish vaccine efficacy. It was noted that men exhibited a 30% lower vaccine response compared to women. Smokers experienced the most significant reduction, with their antibody levels measuring 240% lower than those of nonsmokers. "Almost all of [the smokers] were unable to mount a strong antibody response," remarked senior author Dr. Elissa Epel, vice chair of the UCSF Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences.

The study received funding from the National Institute on Aging.

title: Coolum to host Grand Final of Tier 1 women's cricket final on Australia's Sunshine Coast
content:
**Wednesday, February 15, 2023**  
Coolum will host the Grand Final in the top division of women’s cricket on Australia’s Sunshine Coast, following their victory over Glasshouse on Sunday. Coolum triumphed in the semi-final at Ron Cargill Oval with an 18-run advantage.

“It’s awesome. The girls played really well,” said Coolum captain Sammy Franks. “It’ll be nice to send Kez off. This is her last season, so having a Grand Final at home gives us a great opportunity to win and give her a proper send-off.”

Hinterland has advanced to the premiership decider after Caloundra forfeited their match. Franks is unfazed by the extra rest her team’s Grand Final opponent will have. "I think we fielded really well," she commented. "We have a solid bowling line-up, so I believe we can give them a strong challenge. Hopefully, we can hit a few more boundaries and increase our runs on the board, as we’ll need that to defend against their big score."

title: Saudi Arabia announces astronaut to be nation's first female space traveler
content:
**Wednesday, February 15, 2023**

On Sunday, the Saudi Press Agency (SPA) announced the selection of Rayyanah Barnawi as Saudi Arabia's first female astronaut, who will participate in a private mission to the International Space Station (ISS) later this year. This makes her the kingdom's inaugural female space traveler. 

Axiom Space, the operator of the mission, identified the other three crew members for the Ax-2 mission: Saudi astronaut Ali Al-Qarni, retired NASA astronaut Peggy Whitson—who has completed three ISS missions—and Tennessee businessman John Shoffner, designated as the mission's pilot.

The SPA confirmed that SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket will launch the mission from Launch Complex 39A at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, U.S.

With this endeavor, oil-rich Saudi Arabia is following in the footsteps of its neighbor, the United Arab Emirates, which became the first Arab nation to send a citizen into space in 2019.

According to Agence France-Presse, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the kingdom's de facto leader, has been working to reshape Saudi Arabia's image by implementing reforms, including the initiation of a space program in 2018.

title: Russian authorities charge US reporter Evan Gershkovich with espionage
content:
**Wednesday, April 12, 2023**

On Friday, Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) formally charged journalist Evan Gershkovich, a US citizen working for The Wall Street Journal, with espionage. Gershkovich, 31, has "categorically denied" the allegations, stating that he was simply reporting, according to a source from TASS.

In a joint statement released on Friday, US Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (Democrat) and Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (Republican) declared: "Let there be no mistake: journalism is not a crime... We demand the baseless, fabricated charges against Mr. Gershkovich be dropped and that he be immediately released. We reiterate our condemnation of the Russian government's ongoing attempts to intimidate, repress, and punish independent journalists and civil society voices."

The FSB arrested Gershkovich in Yekaterinburg, located in Russia's Ural Federal District, on March 30, accusing him of "acting at the behest of the American side" and gathering information that constitutes a state secret related to an enterprise within Russia's military-industrial complex. This marks the first instance since the Cold War in which Russia has charged a US journalist with espionage.

The Wall Street Journal has called for an end to the detention of its "trusted and dedicated reporter," labeling the situation "a vicious affront to a free press," and urging outrage among free people and governments worldwide.

On April 3, national security spokesperson John Kirby stated during a briefing: "We will do everything we can to get Evan home [...] I don't have specific details regarding what it would take to negotiate with the Russians for his release."

The following day, Karine Jean-Pierre, the US president's press secretary, told reporters: "Evan is not a spy; Evan has never been a spy [...] This is a case that is a priority for the president."

Gershkovich first met with his attorneys on April 4. By the next day, he had been jailed at Lefortovo Prison in eastern Moscow. The Washington Post reported that Lefortovo is notorious for isolating prisoners; it was originally constructed for the Russian Empire’s military in 1881 and later used by the Soviet KGB.

title: President Tsai says Chinese military drills in Taiwan Strait create instability in region
content:
Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen issued a statement on April 11, asserting that China's recent three-day military drills in the Taiwan Strait have created instability in the region. The Associated Press reported that these drills were a reaction to Tsai's recent visit to the United States, where she met with House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, marking the highest-level meeting between a US politician and a Taiwanese president on American soil.

In her statement, Tsai emphasized her role as the representative of Taiwan on the international stage, saying, "As the president, I represent our country in the world, whether it's a visit to allied countries or a stop in the U.S. to engage with our international friends. This has been a longstanding practice and is a shared expectation of the Taiwanese people." She criticized China for using her visit as a pretext for military exercises, declaring, "This creates instability in the Taiwan Strait and the wider region. This is not the behavior of a responsible major nation."

On Saturday, China conducted military drills that simulated strikes on Taiwan utilizing carrier-based aircraft. The Japan Joint Chiefs of Staff reported observing 80 aircraft take-offs and landings from the Chinese aircraft carrier Shandong, prompting Japan to scramble its Air Self-Defense Force fighter jets in response. CNN noted that 35 aircraft from the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) crossed the median line of the Taiwan Strait or entered Taiwan’s air-defense identification zone.

In a statement, the PLA claimed the operation "comprehensively tested the joint combat capabilities of its integrated military forces under actual combat conditions," and asserted that its forces are "ready for combat at all times" to "resolutely destroy any type of 'Taiwan independence' separatist or foreign interference attempts."

The Taiwan Relations Act, enacted by the US in 1979, formalized unofficial relations with Taiwan and mandates that the US "provide Taiwan with arms of a defensive character."

title: Russian missiles strike buildings in Sloviansk, Ukraine, killing at least 11
content:
**Saturday, April 15, 2023**

On Saturday, Ukrainian authorities in Sloviansk reported that at least 11 people were killed and 21 others injured after seven Russian S-300 missiles struck the city on Friday, just ahead of Orthodox Easter. 

Pavlo Kyrylenko, the governor of the partially occupied Donetsk region, stated that the S-300 missiles, originally designed for surface-to-air defense, were responsible for the attack. 

The missiles targeted a residential area, and among the victims was a two-year-old boy who succumbed to his injuries while being transported to the hospital.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy condemned the attack in a statement, saying, "The evil state once again demonstrates its essence [...] Just killing people in broad daylight. Ruining, destroying all life." 

Zelenskyy further emphasized on Twitter: "Not a single hour of this week before Orthodox Easter passed without [Russian] murders and terror. This is an evil state, and it will lose. To win is our duty to humanity as such. And we will win! The longer-range Ukrainian strikes are, the sooner Russian atrocities will end."

Sloviansk is located 45 kilometers (28 miles) northwest of the contested city of Bakhmut.

title: India launches Small Satellite Launch Vehicle, deploying three low-earth orbit satellites
content:
**Sunday, February 12, 2023**

On Friday, India's national space agency, the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), successfully conducted the second test flight of its Small Satellite Launch Vehicle (SSLV-D2), carrying three satellites on board. The launch occurred at 9:18 AM Indian Standard Time (3:48 AM UTC) from the first launchpad at the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, Andhra Pradesh.

After a 15-minute flight, all three satellites were successfully placed into a 450-kilometer (280-mile) orbit. The payload included ISRO's Earth Observation Satellite-7 (EOS-07), weighing 156.3 kilograms (344.6 lbs), the US-based company Antaris' Janus-1, which weighs 10.2 kilograms (22.5 lbs), and AzaadiSAT-2, built by 750 female students and weighing 8.8 kilograms (19.4 lbs).

ISRO celebrated the flight’s success with a tweet stating: "SSLV-D2/EOS-07 Mission accomplished successfully. SSLV-D2 placed EOS-07, Janus-1, and AzaadiSAT-2 into their intended orbits."

This success follows the SSLV's first test flight on August 7, which ended in failure when the vehicle ejected its payload as planned but propelled it into an unstable orbit, preventing sufficient velocity to maintain the correct trajectory.

The SSLV is designed to cater to commercial satellites weighing up to 500 kilograms (1,100 lbs) in the small and micro-satellite market, operating on a 'launch-on-demand' basis. According to the Times of India, the rocket's designers aim to offer low-cost, quick, and flexible access to space while requiring minimal launch infrastructure.

title: Médecins Sans Frontières closes hospital amid rising violence in Haiti
content:
**Sunday, March 12, 2023**

Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), also known as Doctors Without Borders, announced on Wednesday the temporary closure of their hospital located in the Cité Soleil district of Port-au-Prince, Haiti. The decision was made in response to escalating gang violence, which has made it impossible for the organization to ensure the safety of patients and staff.

In the week leading up to the announcement, heavily armed groups expanded their territory to include areas of Port-au-Prince and surrounding towns, with stray bullets striking near the hospital and clashes occurring just meters away. This violence has also led to the closure of local schools.

Vincent Harris, a medical advisor for MSF, stated, "While the hospital has not been directly targeted, we have become collateral victims of the fighting, as our facility sits on the frontline. We understand that this closure will significantly affect the residents of Cité Soleil, but our teams cannot operate until security conditions improve."

Alexandre Marcou, the field communication manager, stressed that MSF is not abandoning Haiti and plans to increase their aid efforts when it is safe to do so.

Gang violence in Haiti has surged since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse in July 2021, leading to increases in murder, kidnapping, and sexual violence aimed at terrorizing the population. According to a November report from the United Nations, gangs now control approximately 60% of the capital.

Haiti's acting prime minister, Ariel Henry, has called for an international force to help restore order, a request that has garnered support from the UN and the United States. However, US efforts have stalled as no other country has agreed to lead a non-UN mission.

Earlier this year, another hospital supported by MSF south of Port-au-Prince closed after a patient was killed while leaving the emergency room.

title: China's Foreign Ministry sanctions US Representative Michael McCaul
content:
**Sunday, April 16, 2023**

China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced sanctions against Michael McCaul, the Republican chair of the United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs, on Thursday. The sanctions were imposed after McCaul led a delegation of lawmakers to Taiwan last week, which China criticized for "sending a serious wrong signal to Taiwan independence separatist forces."

According to the Ministry's statement, the sanctions include freezing any assets McCaul may have in China, prohibiting organizations and individuals in China from engaging with him, and denying him entry visas. 

During McCaul's delegation visit to Taipei, which included a meeting with President Tsai Ing-wen, McCaul reportedly pledged to enhance training for Taiwanese military forces and expedite arms deliveries, as reported by Reuters. 

Taiwan separated from China in 1949 during the Chinese Civil War; however, the mainland continues to assert that Taiwan lacks the authority to conduct foreign relations. The Ministry's statement emphasized that McCaul has "frequently taken actions that interfere in China’s internal affairs and undermine China's interests," and highlighted his recent visit to Taiwan as a grave violation of the one-China principle and the trilateral relationship between China and the United States.

In response, McCaul stated, "Ironically, this baseless action serves US interests by drawing more attention to our international partners and exposing the [Chinese Communist Party's] blatant aggression." 

Historically, China has imposed sanctions on foreign officials and entities for supporting Taiwan, including actions taken last Wednesday against the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library and others for hosting a meeting between Tsai and US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Additionally, Beijing has targeted senior Taiwanese lawmakers. 

Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs asserted on Sunday that it has a "fundamental right" to conduct its own diplomacy.

title: UK Treasury considering plans for digital pound, economic secretary says
content:
**Monday, January 16, 2023**

Andrew Griffith, the Economic Secretary to HM Treasury, informed members of the United Kingdom House of Commons on Tuesday that the government is considering the introduction of a "digital pound" and plans to conduct public consultations regarding the features and regulations of digital assets in the upcoming weeks. 

While addressing Parliament's Treasury Select Committee, Griffith noted that the government is well underway in establishing a regulatory framework for the wholesale use of stablecoins, which are cryptocurrencies designed to minimize price volatility by being pegged to traditional assets. 

He emphasized that while the UK aims to become a cryptocurrency hub, the creation of regulations for a digital pound would be a lengthy process. Griffith indicated that the initial application of a digital pound is expected to be for settling wholesale financial transactions; however, he suggested that existing private, fiat-backed stablecoins could fulfill this role in the meantime due to public policy considerations. 

"I would rather be right than be first," he stated, stressing the importance of addressing public policy issues accurately. Griffith hopes that the first regulatory framework for crypto assets in the UK will be incorporated into the Financial Services and Markets Bill currently under discussion in the House of Lords. He noted that adopting "potentially disruptive game-changing technology" could greatly benefit the UK's fintech and financial sectors.

Globally, central banks are actively exploring digital currencies, with China piloting a digital yuan in major cities like Beijing and Shanghai. The European Union (EU) is also set to release draft legislation later this year to establish and regulate a digital euro. The European Central Bank is expected to conclude its two-year investigation into a digital euro in July, leading to three years of implementation.

Consumer protection has become a key concern during the challenging period for cryptocurrencies, which has seen a decline in Bitcoin's value and the collapse of the major exchange FTX. The EU has introduced comprehensive regulations for crypto markets, set to take effect in 2024. Griffith indicated that the UK's regulatory framework might be more expansive, encompassing decentralized finance, and that the upcoming consultations on crypto asset regulation will be part of a "research and exploration" initiative along with the Bank of England.

This process will involve at least six discussions with industry stakeholders to enhance understanding among regulators and decision-makers, thereby strengthening Britain's "strong financial reputation."

title: G7 finance chiefs, central bankers commit to implementing plan to diversify supply chains by year's end
content:
**Tuesday, May 16, 2023**

Finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven (G7) concluded a three-day summit in Niigata, Japan, on Saturday, issuing a communiqué that pledged to implement a plan to diversify supply chains by the end of the year. The statement emphasized the need for vigilance, agility, and flexibility in macroeconomic policy amid rising uncertainty regarding the global economic outlook.

The proposed plan aims to enhance the role of low- and middle-income countries within energy-related supply chains through targeted aid. The communiqué highlighted that "diversification of supply chains can contribute to safeguarding energy security and help us maintain macroeconomic stability."

The leaders credited legislation enacted during the Great Recession for keeping markets "resilient" against potential banking system turmoil. The central bank officials reaffirmed their commitment to addressing "elevated" inflation levels.

Additionally, the group expressed intentions to enforce sanctions on Russia in response to its invasion of Ukraine, calling for an immediate end to the "illegal war," which they identified as a significant source of global economic uncertainty.

Japanese Finance Minister Shun'ichi Suzuki addressed the press, stating, "Through the pandemic, we learned that supply chains often depended on a limited number of countries or even just one," which led to shortages of critical items like medicines and computer chips across many nations. He emphasized that economic security during the transition to clean energy relies heavily on diversifying these supply chains.

Suzuki also noted that attendees discussed the potential for the United States to default on its debts during a dinner on Thursday, though he did not provide further details. While this topic was not included in the official communiqué, Reuters reported it was a significant point of discussion.

U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen previously cautioned that a default could happen within weeks if Congress fails to raise the national debt ceiling. United Kingdom Chancellor Jeremy Hunt remarked that such an outcome would be "absolutely devastating."

G7 leaders are set to convene starting Friday in Hiroshima.

title: Loreen wins Eurovision for Sweden for second time
content:
**Wednesday, May 17, 2023**

On Saturday, 39-year-old Swedish singer Loreen claimed her second victory at the Eurovision Song Contest held at the Liverpool Arena in the United Kingdom. Her song "Tattoo" garnered a total of 583 points, combining scores from both the public and expert juries.

Finland and Israel secured the second and third spots, respectively, with 526 and 362 points. Out of the 37 participating countries, 26, including the previous year's winner Ukraine and the Big Five—France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom—competed in the final. Serbia, the UK, and Germany finished at the bottom, with Germany receiving just 18 points and the UK only 24.

The juries awarded Sweden 340 points, significantly outscoring Italy, which came in second with 163 points. This score included multiple 12-point awards, the highest a jury can assign. Finland's Käärijä, representing the song "Cha Cha Cha," earned 150 points, placing fifth, while Finland topped the public vote with 243 points, finishing ahead of Sweden in that category.

Criticism arose on social media regarding the jury's impact on the final results. Additionally, accusations of plagiarism were directed at "Tattoo," with comparisons made to songs like Marc Escudero and Ruben Moreno's "Flying Free," ABBA's "The Winner Takes It All," Adele's "Easy on Me," and Ukrainian artist Mika Newton's "V plenu."

This year's contest was hosted by the UK on behalf of Ukraine, the 2022 winner, due to the ongoing Russian invasion. Ukrainian duo Tvorchi finished sixth with 243 points, despite their hometown Ternopil being subjected to a missile attack just before their performance.

Following Loreen's victory, Sweden is set to host Eurovision in 2024. Loreen previously won the contest for Sweden in 2012 with "Euphoria," making her the first woman to win Eurovision twice and only the second artist overall, following Ireland's Johnny Logan, who won in 1980 and 1987.

title: Scientists: Rock that hit New Jersey home is 4.6 billion-year-old meteorite
content:
**Thursday, May 18, 2023**

Scientists confirmed on Thursday that a rock weighing approximately 2.2 pounds, which fell on a home in Hopewell Township, New Jersey, on May 8, is a meteorite, with an estimated age of 4.56 billion years. 

Suzy Kop, who discovered the meteorite, brought it to The College of New Jersey for analysis to confirm if it was indeed an extraterrestrial object. Researchers Shannon Graham and Nathan Magee from the college's physics department conducted tests that included measuring the rock's density and examining it with an electron microscope.

Initial assessments indicated that the rock is an LL6 chondrite, a type of stony meteorite with small concentrations of iron. While local police initially speculated that the meteorite may have been connected to the Eta Aquariids meteor shower, an analysis by Sky & Telescope later ruled out this possibility, clarifying its trajectory.

Kop discovered the warm, black rock on her father's bedroom floor around 12:30 PM (UTC−04:00) and noted two holes in the ceiling that scientists confirmed were created by the meteorite upon impact, which caused it to bounce off the floor. After contacting authorities, a hazmat team was dispatched to assess the situation, determining that the rock posed no significant radioactive threat.

Fortunately, no injuries were reported as a result of the impact.

title: Sudan warring forces sign agreement to protect civilians, aid workers
content:
**Revised News Article**

**Wednesday, May 17, 2023**

Representatives from Sudan's conflict parties, the army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), reached a declaration of principles on Thursday in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, committing to the safety of civilians, aid workers, and humanitarian assistance. 

The declaration emphasizes that both sides "affirm our commitment to ensuring the protection of civilians at all times," which includes facilitating safe passage for civilians wishing to leave active conflict zones voluntarily and towards their preferred destinations. Additionally, it instructs forces to vacate public and private properties, including hospitals and energy facilities, and to ensure "respectful burial of the dead." 

Volker Perthes, the United Nations (UN) Special Representative in Sudan, stated on Friday, "The most significant aspect of this understanding is that both sides commit to continuing their discussions." 

A U.S. representative involved in the negotiations clarified, "This is not a ceasefire; it is an affirmation of their obligations under international humanitarian law, particularly concerning the treatment of civilians and the necessity for humanitarian operations." 

Cameron Hudson from the Center for Strategic and International Studies expressed skepticism, stating, "These are actions they should already be taking without external prompting. They deserve no credit for this." He raised concerns about whether the RSF could effectively prevent its troops from violating the agreement. 

Humanitarian organizations, including UN agencies, previously halted operations in Khartoum and Darfur due to escalating violence. Since the conflict erupted on April 15, at least 18 aid workers and over 750 individuals in total have lost their lives. 

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has reported that approximately 200,000 people have fled the country, and around 700,000 have been displaced internally. At a human rights summit in Geneva, Switzerland, Western nations accused both the RSF and the army of committing human rights violations.

title: Tensions increase as US recovers downed Chinese "spy balloon" debris
content:
**Thursday, February 16, 2023**

The United States announced on Monday that a "significant" portion of the payload from a Chinese high-altitude balloon shot down over the Atlantic Ocean on February 4 has been recovered. Officials previously stated on February 9 that the balloon was "likely capable of collecting and geo-locating communications" after part of its wreckage was sent to a Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) lab for analysis. They alleged that China was conducting an espionage program targeting over 40 countries and linked the balloon to that initiative.

China acknowledged ownership of the balloon, asserting that it was a meteorological research craft that had been blown off course by unexpected winds.

US officials believe the balloon entered American airspace on January 28. On February 3, US Department of Defense Press Secretary Brigadier General Patrick S. Ryder confirmed that the balloon was floating eastward at about 60,000 feet (18,300 meters) above the central United States and exhibited the ability to maneuver using motors and propellers. Ryder noted that it was "well above civilian air traffic" and assessed that it did not pose a physical threat to people on the ground.

Presidential Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre called the balloon's flight path over the US a "clear violation of our sovereignty." US Secretary of State Antony Blinken canceled his scheduled trip to Beijing on February 4, calling the balloon's presence in US airspace an "irresponsible act" during a discussion with Chinese diplomat Wang Yi. The trip was intended to include talks on strengthening communications and reducing tensions between the two nations.

Advisors informed US President Joe Biden that the military should wait to shoot down the balloon until it was over water to avoid endangering civilians. He authorized the downing of the balloon on February 4 as it drifted off the coast of South Carolina. 

China condemned the downing of the balloon, describing it as "an obvious overreaction and a serious violation of international practice," while stating it reserved "the right to take further actions in response." Biden, speaking on Air Force One while en route to Camp David, Maryland, praised the military's actions, saying, "They successfully took it down, and I want to compliment our aviators who did it."

In addition, a second balloon was reported to have crossed Latin America; on February 3, Ryder confirmed this, stating, "We now assess it is another Chinese surveillance balloon." In a February 6 statement, China admitted ownership of this second balloon as well, maintaining that it was also a civilian weather balloon that had been diverted from its intended path by wind.

US officials indicated this was not the first incident of balloons crossing US airspace, asserting that at least three such occurrences happened during Donald Trump's presidency and another earlier during Biden's tenure, although those flights were shorter in duration.

title: US actress and model Raquel Welch dies at age 82
content:
**Thursday, February 16, 2023**

Raquel Welch, the renowned US actress and model, passed away yesterday in Los Angeles, California, as announced by her manager, Stephen LaManna. She was 82 years old and had recently battled a brief illness.

Welch was one of the most prominent actresses of her era, boasting a diverse career with 30 films and 50 television roles. Born Jo-Raquel Tejada in Chicago, Illinois, in 1940, she grew up in California, where she dominated teen beauty pageants before working as a local weather forecaster.

After two divorces and the raising of her two children, she lived in Texas, modeling for Neiman Marcus and serving as a cocktail waitress. In 1964, she returned to California, making brief appearances in the drama *A House Is Not A Home* and the musical *Roustabout*, which ultimately led to her big break.

Welch gained international fame following her iconic performance as a bikini-clad cavewoman in *One Million Years B.C.* in 1966, solidifying her status as a sex symbol. In the 1970s, her role as Constance de Bonacieux in the classic film *The Three Musketeers* earned her a Golden Globe award.

Despite her status as a sex symbol, Welch expressed discomfort with the sexualization of her body. In her autobiography, *Raquel: Beyond the Cleavage*, she reflected, "The irony of it all is that, even though people thought of me as a sex symbol, in reality I was a single mother of two small children!"

title: Bangladesh President-elect meets outgoing president Hamid at Bangabhaban
content:
**Friday, February 17, 2023**

On Tuesday, President-elect of Bangladesh Mohammad Shahabuddin Chuppu met with outgoing President Mohammad Abdul Hamid at the presidential palace in Dhaka, known as Bangabhaban. On Monday, the election commission announced that Chuppu would become Bangladesh's 22nd president.

An official from the presidential palace told the Press Trust of India: "The president-elect met President Hamid and the First Lady, who greeted him with a bouquet at Bangabhaban this evening (Tuesday) during a courtesy call." The official also noted that Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her sister Sheikh Rehana were present during Chuppu's visit.

Chuppu ran as an independent candidate with support from the ruling Awami League (AL) party and faced no opponents for the position. The AL holds a majority in the Jatiya Sangsad, Bangladesh's national parliament, with 302 members in the 350-seat legislature.

The opposition party in parliament, the Jatiya Party, chose not to nominate a candidate for the presidency. Additionally, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), which is outside parliament, could not propose a candidate after all its members resigned in December 2022.

The presidential election was originally scheduled for February 19, with the nomination process concluding on Sunday.

A veteran of the Bangladesh Liberation War in 1971, Chuppu was born in 1949 and hails from the northern Pabna District. He was a student leader in the AL during the Liberation War and is a retired district judge. Chuppu has also served as a member of the AL's Advisory Council.

Chuppu's inauguration is set for April 24, 2023.

title: European Council agrees to crypto asset regulations
content:
**Friday, May 19, 2023**

On Tuesday, the European Council, representing EU member states, approved the Markets in Crypto Assets (MiCA) regulations, which Reuters has noted as the most comprehensive regulations of their kind globally. The Council's endorsement followed the European Parliament's approval in April and initiates a phased rollout of the regulations, which have been in the legislative pipeline since 2020, starting from July 2024.

Elisabeth Svantesson, Finance Minister for Sweden, the Council presidency holder, emphasized the need for these regulations: "Recent events have confirmed the urgent need for rules that will better protect European investors in these assets and prevent the misuse of the crypto industry for money laundering and terrorism financing."

Under the new regulations, companies involved in the issuance, trading, and insurance of crypto assets, including stablecoins, will be required to obtain a license to operate within the EU. Noncompliant firms will be publicly identified by the bloc. The new framework aims to maintain market stability while mitigating manipulation and insider trading, according to the Associated Press.

MiCA will impose liability on firms for losses and mandate disclosure of risks and fees to investors. Starting in January 2026, companies must also keep records of parties involved in crypto transfers, a measure anticipated to support enforcement of taxation and anti-money laundering laws. Additionally, MiCA aims to enhance member cooperation on taxation for crypto assets.

This approval from the Council comes in the wake of numerous collapses in the crypto industry, including the bankruptcy of exchange FTX and the downfall of the TerraUSD stablecoin. Some industry representatives have called for greater international regulatory consistency. Meanwhile, the United Kingdom has expressed intentions to regulate stablecoins and is currently reviewing responses to proposed policies from last year.

Hester Peirce, a commissioner at the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission, remarked that officials at various government levels in the U.S. are evaluating their roles in the crypto market, stating at a conference: "We are wandering in the desert a bit."

title: Tennessee, US former police officers plead not guilty in Tyre Nichols' death
content:
**February 18, 2023**

Five former police officers charged in connection with the fatal beating of 29-year-old Tyre Nichols in Memphis, Tennessee, pleaded not guilty yesterday. The officers—Demetrius Haley, Tadarrius Bean, Justin Smith, Emmitt Martin III, and Desmond Mills, Jr.—are currently free on bail and face charges of second-degree murder, aggravated kidnapping, aggravated assault, official misconduct, and official oppression.

Shelby County Criminal Court Judge James Jones has scheduled the next hearing for May 1. "We understand that there may be some high emotions in this case," Judge Jones said, urging patience from the community.

All involved, including Nichols and the officers, are African American. On January 7, officers stopped Nichols while he was returning home from work, alleging he was driving recklessly. Body camera footage shows Haley pulling Nichols from his car and issuing commands, while Nichols attempted to communicate before fleeing. Officers Smith, Bean, and Mills, Jr. apprehended him, during which Haley kicked Nichols, and Mills, Jr. used pepper spray and a baton against him.

One officer later claimed that Nichols attempted to grab his gun during the altercation. Police records indicate that Haley took photos of the injured Nichols as he lay handcuffed and sent them to multiple recipients. Nichols, critically injured, was transported by ambulance to St. Francis Hospital, where he died on January 10.

Following the incident, the five officers were terminated from the police force and indicted, with their crime unit, SCORPION, subsequently disbanded. Two additional officers were relieved of duty, and seven others are under investigation. The Memphis Fire Department dismissed three emergency medical technicians for failing to provide care to Nichols, while the county sheriff suspended two deputies who were present during the incident.

Van Turner, President of the Memphis Branch of the NAACP, stated, "If you were an officer or first responder and you sat there and watched this young man die without taking action to help resuscitate him, you're just as culpable as those who beat him down and killed him."

Nichols' family, attorneys, and community activists are advocating for police reform in the wake of his tragic death.

title: Bulgarian police arrest four over eighteen dead migrants in abandoned truck
content:
**Revised News Article**  
**Date: Monday, February 20, 2023**  

Bulgarian officials reported on Friday that police discovered the bodies of eighteen dead migrants, including a child, in an abandoned truck in Lokorsko, approximately 12 miles (19 km) northeast of Sofia, the capital.  

Authorities have arrested four individuals and transported 34 people to the hospital, including five children, some of whom are in critical but stable condition. This incident is believed to be the deadliest involving migrants in Bulgaria to date, with survivors described as "freezing, wet, and having not eaten for several days."  

The truck, which had been carrying timber, contained migrants in concealed compartments, according to the Ministry of Interior. Health Minister Asen Medzhidiev stated, "There has been a lack of oxygen for those locked in this truck," while Borislav Sarafov, head of the National Investigative Service, indicated that some migrants had suffocated.  

Police suspect the migrants were from Afghanistan and were being smuggled to Serbia along a route frequently used by Middle Eastern migrants attempting to reach the European Union. Sarafov reported that the migrants had illegally entered Bulgaria from Turkey and had spent two days in the woods before boarding the truck near Yambol.  

One of the individuals arrested has a previous conviction for human trafficking, and official Atanas Ilkov told Reuters that additional charges are pending based on further evidence.  

In December, Austria and the Netherlands blocked Bulgaria's accession to the passport-free Schengen Area due to an increase in asylum seekers using the Western Balkans route and concerns about the Bulgarian government's efforts to address crime.  

Both Bulgaria and its northern neighbor Romania, which also faced opposition from Austria regarding its entry to the Schengen Area, are situated along the Western Balkan migration route, a point of contention for Bucharest.  

The EU's external border control agency, Frontex, reported that 61,375 migrants entered the EU via this route in 2021, predominantly through Bulgaria or Greece, targeting common destinations such as Croatia, Hungary, Romania, or Serbia.  

The Ministry of Interior indicated that over 12,740 migrants were detained in Bulgaria during the first nine months of 2022, with attempted border crossings from January to August doubling to 80,000 compared to 2021 figures.

title: Study: floods, droughts more intense in past 20 years due to higher global temperatures
content:
**Revised Version:**

**March 19, 2023**

A study published by Nature Water on Monday, conducted by scientists Matthew Rodell and Bailing Li from NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, establishes a "strong" link between global mean surface temperature and an increase in the severity of water-related extreme weather events, such as floods and droughts, over the past two decades.

Rodell and Li's findings suggest that rising temperatures are correlated with a marked increase in the intensity and metrics of hydroclimatic extremes, which cannot solely be explained by natural climate variations like the El Niño–Southern Oscillation. Through a new algorithm that utilized data from the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE) and GRACE Follow-On (GRACE-FO) satellites, the researchers identified 1,066 regions that experienced periods of excessive rainfall or drought between 2002 and 2021. This analysis revealed 505 'wet' clusters and 561 'dry' clusters, with a notable escalation in event severity over the past seven years, particularly since 2015, which ranks among the hottest years recorded. The occurrence of 'most extreme' events (among the 30 wettest or driest) rose from three to four per year during 2015 to 2021.

The study reported an increase in the wet-to-dry event ratio from 15° S to 20° N, while noting a decrease in three regions between 15° N and 50° N, supporting the hypothesis that extreme events inversely affect wet and dry areas. The most intense drought recorded was the South American drought from 2015 to 2016, while significant flooding persisted in sub-Saharan Africa from 2002 to 2021, peaking with Lake Victoria reaching its highest levels in 2020.

Rodell expressed surprise at the strong correlation between global intensity and temperatures, stating to the Associated Press, "I was surprised to see how well correlated the global intensity was with global mean temperatures." He elaborated to CNN, acknowledging a significant connection between the overall intensity of these events and temperature records during the warmest years.

Addressing the study's implications, Rodell emphasized that as the world warms, the intensity and frequency of wet and dry events are likely to increase. “The study underscores the pervasive impact of climate change,” he noted, highlighting that rising temperatures lead to more severe weather events affecting people globally.

Climate specialist Richard Seager from Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory warned that future water resource and flood management strategies should anticipate that both wet extremes will become wetter and dry extremes drier, emphasizing that human-driven warming amplifies climate extremes.

Park Williams, a bioclimatologist at UCLA, remarked on the significance of using satellite monitoring to understand continental water patterns, indicating that this research will be pivotal for future generations seeking to grasp humanity's evolving understanding of the Earth's systems.

CNN also quoted climatologist Kim Cobb, Director of the Brown University Institute for Environment and Society, who described the study as providing a "new lens" on the changing water cycle, linking various incidents of droughts, floods, and wildfires to the global analysis. She stated that the findings bolster existing trends seen in rainfall data and climate model outputs, offering crucial evidence for emergency planning, infrastructure development, agricultural practices, and water resource management amid ongoing global warming.

Rodell has served as Acting Deputy Director of Earth Sciences for Hydrosphere, Biosphere, and Geophysics at Goddard since 2021, while Li has been an assistant research scientist at Goddard and the University of Maryland since 2017.

The United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change reported in 2021 a 70% increase in the frequency of droughts that typically occur every decade, along with a 30% rise in flooding events. Furthermore, scientists warn that global warming could heighten instances of 'weather whiplash', characterized by rapid shifts between extreme weather conditions, as seen recently in California, which has suffered both a megadrought and severe rainstorms.

According to the National Integrated Drought Information System, droughts and floods account for approximately 20% of annual extreme weather-related economic losses in the United States.

title: US Interior Department approves Willow oil project in Alaska
content:
**Tuesday, March 21, 2023**

The U.S. Department of the Interior approved ConocoPhillips' Willow oil drilling proposal in Alaska's National Petroleum Reserve–Alaska (NPR–A) on March 13. The Department revoked leases covering 68,000 acres (275 square kilometers) within the Bear Tooth Unit in the northeast NPR–A, while granting three out of ConocoPhillips' requested five drilling sites.

According to the Department's record of decision, the approved plan "requires the fewest ice roads, fewest total miles of infield pipelines, least water use, fewest vehicle trips, fewest fixed-wing aircraft trips, fewest helicopter trips, and fewest acres of screeding." U.S. Senator Lisa Murkowski, an Alaska Republican, expressed her relief on Twitter the same day, stating: "I'm so relieved that an economically viable Willow Project is being reapproved. What a huge and needed victory for all Alaska."

A January Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement (SEIS) from the Bureau of Land Management (BLM) outlined the project's potential environmental impacts, estimating it would destroy approximately 532 acres (2 km²) of wetlands, consume around 1.5 billion gallons (5.7 billion liters) of freshwater, and emit approximately 613 trillion pounds (278,036 metric megatons) of gross carbon dioxide equivalent over its planned 30-year duration.

The development of the project's master plan began in 2018, with the BLM releasing its Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) on August 15, 2020. At that time, Audubon Alaska and several indigenous and conservation organizations criticized the process, claiming the Trump Administration was rushing to accommodate ConocoPhillips' timeline without adequately considering local community input.

The Department of the Interior issued a Record of Decision on October 26, 2020, authorizing up to three drill sites along with supporting infrastructure, including processing and support facilities, gravel access roads, and pipelines. Secretary of the Interior David Bernhardt noted that this decision would help sustain oil flow through the 800-mile Trans Alaska Pipeline for decades while also providing federal and state revenue and assistance to affected native communities.

However, on February 13, 2021, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit temporarily blocked ConocoPhillips from commencing construction activities related to the Willow project. The following August, a U.S. District Court in Anchorage overturned the August 2020 EIS, stating it failed to analyze foreign greenhouse gas emissions, overlooked alternative proposals, and did not adequately address the Naval Petroleum Reserves Production Act's mandate to prioritize "maximum protection" for surface values in the Teshekpuk Lake Special Area (TLSA).

In January 2021, President Joe Biden signed an executive order pausing "new oil and natural gas leases on public lands or in offshore waters," fulfilling a campaign promise. U.S. District Judge Terry A. Doughty subsequently issued a preliminary injunction against this pause, making it permanent last August and asserting that the administration lacked the authority to halt lease sales.

The Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 mandated the U.S. Department of the Interior to lease the lesser of 60 million acres (240,000 km²) offshore and 2 million acres (8,100 km²) of federal lands annually for oil and gas development, along with any amount requested by industry. The Willow project received backing from various Alaska Native organizations and all three members of Alaska's bipartisan congressional delegation, who emphasized its economic significance for local communities. Senator Dan Sullivan, also an Alaska Republican, described it as "one of the biggest, most important resource development projects in our state's history." On February 20, the Alaska House of Representatives unanimously passed House Joint Resolution 6, expressing support for the project.

Nevertheless, Sierra Club Senior Campaign Representative Mike Scott condemned the project, stating: "The Willow project would have a devastating effect on public lands and our climate. Approving it after passing the largest climate bill in history would be a giant step in reverse."

title: Paris judge acquits Airbus, Air France of involuntary manslaughter in 2009 crash that killed 228
content:
**Friday, April 21, 2023**

On Monday, a judge in Paris found Air France and Airbus not guilty of involuntary manslaughter in the 2009 crash of Air France Flight 447 (AF447), which resulted in the deaths of all 228 people onboard. This marked the conclusion of the first corporate manslaughter trial in French history. Judge Sylvie Daunis acknowledged that Airbus had demonstrated negligence on four occasions and Air France on one, but emphasized that "a probable causal link isn't sufficient to characterize an offense." She reaffirmed the corporations' civil liability, noting that Air France had previously compensated families of the victims and scheduled a hearing for additional civil damages on September 4.

If convicted, both companies faced potential fines of up to €225,000 each. Air France-KLM reported revenue of €7.1 billion in the fourth quarter of 2022, while Airbus reported €20.64 billion for the same period. Additionally, Reuters reported that the parties had reached undisclosed settlements.

Claire Durousseau, whose niece was among the 216 passengers from 33 countries aboard AF447, expressed her devastation following the verdict, stating, "Our lost ones have died a second time. I feel sick." Danièle Lamy, president of the victims' families association Entraide et Solidarité AF447, described the families as "mortified and overwhelmed" after enduring over a decade of "chaotic" legal disputes, including the nine-week trial last year. "The loser first and foremost is French justice," she remarked.

Attorney Alain Jakubowicz, representing the families, stated, "We're told Air France and Airbus are responsible, but not guilty. We were waiting for the word 'guilty'." Both defendants expressed their sympathy towards the families and reiterated their commitment to enhancing safety.

The plaintiffs, consisting of victims' family members, contended that the prosecution's arguments for acquittal were based on a lack of evidence linking corporate liability to the crash, noting that the pilots were ultimately responsible. Air France asserted that the exact causes of the accident may never be known.

Judge Daunis found Airbus negligent for failing to replace the model of pitot tubes—airspeed sensors with a history of issues—and for not appropriately analyzing incident reports to identify problems with the sensors. She indicated that the cockpit display did not adequately inform pilots of issues compared to the information provided to air traffic controllers. Investigators relied on encoded alerts to determine the crash's causes before finding the main wreckage in 2011.

The judge also determined that Air France acted negligently by not informing pilots about prior problems with the pitot tubes. AF447, en route from Rio de Janeiro to Paris, disappeared into the Atlantic Ocean on May 31, 2009. The main wreckage was located by robotic submarines from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution on April 3, 2011, and the aircraft's cockpit voice recorders were retrieved in May.

Investigators from the Bureau of Enquiry and Analysis for Civil Aviation Safety (BEA) concluded that ice had accumulated on the pitot tubes, disabling the aircraft’s autopilot and autothrottle, leading to a stall that generated warnings which the pilots ignored—an explanation with which Airbus concurred. Air France, the National Airline Pilots Union, and Entraide et Solidarité AF447 criticized the BEA for allegedly focusing its investigation on the airline rather than probing Airbus. According to Euronews, the AF447 crash led to new regulations concerning sensor testing and pilot training.

title: Former South Carolina governor Nikki Haley declares bid for 2024 US presidential election
content:
**Tuesday, February 21, 2023**

Former South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley announced her candidacy for the Republican nomination in the 2024 United States presidential election last Tuesday. Haley, who previously served as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, is set to challenge her former boss, Donald Trump, the prior president. Other potential contenders include Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, U.S. Senator Tim Scott from South Carolina, former Vice President Mike Pence, and former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, according to Politico. In hypothetical opinion polls, Haley has struggled to keep pace with Trump and DeSantis.

In her announcement video titled "Strong & Proud," Haley stated, "Republicans have lost the popular vote in seven out of the last eight presidential elections. That has to change." She criticized President Joe Biden's record, asserting, "The Washington, D.C. establishment has failed us over and over again. [...] It's time for a new generation of leadership [...] I'm Nikki Haley, and I'm running for president."

The following day, Haley held her inaugural rally in Charleston, South Carolina. According to Politico, the event was more understated compared to Trump's usual energetic rallies.

Taylor Budowich, spokesperson for Trump’s super PAC, Make America Great Again Inc., labeled Haley as "just another career politician," noting that she initially opposed Trump before resigning to serve in his administration. "Now, she's telling us she represents a 'new generation'. Sure just looks like more of the same, a career politician whose only fulfilled commitment is to herself," Budowich remarked.

At 51, Haley contrasted her age with Biden, who is 80, and Trump, who is 76, calling for "mandatory mental competency tests for politicians over 75 years" and urging a move away from "the stale ideas and faded names of the past." She emphasized, "America is not past our prime [...] It’s just that our politicians are past theirs."

Born Nimrata Nikki Randhawa to Sikh immigrants from India in Bamberg, South Carolina, Haley reflected on her heritage in her announcement video, saying, "I was the proud daughter of Indian immigrants: not Black, not white. I was different." If nominated, she would become the first female and first non-white Republican presidential nominee, and if elected, the first female president and the first president of Indian descent in the U.S.

Haley began her political career in 2004, winning her first race against a senior South Carolina state representative. She became the first non-white female governor of a U.S. state in 2010 at the age of 38, won reelection in 2014, and delivered the Republican response to President Barack Obama’s 2016 State of the Union address.

In 2015, following a racially motivated shooting in Charleston, Haley attended the victims' funerals and successfully advocated for the removal of a Confederate flag from the state capitol. She criticized Trump's refusal to condemn the Ku Klux Klan during his 2016 campaign but later expressed her support for him after his election. 

Trump appointed Haley as the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations in 2017. During her time in office, the U.S. withdrew from UNESCO and the UN Human Rights Council, citing their anti-Israel stance. Haley resigned in late 2018, with both she and the Trump administration offering no explanation for her departure, although Trump stated that it had been planned six months prior amid a public disagreement over sanctions on Russia.

title: Viktor Pinchuk presents exhibition Afghanistan, 2008 in Simferopol, Crimea
