title: Sinn Féin becomes largest party in Northern Ireland local government after 2023 elections
content:
Monday, May 22, 2023 

Sinn Féin emerged as the dominant party in the local elections across Northern Ireland's 11 councils, with counting concluding on Saturday. The nationalist party secured 144 of the 462 contested seats, a significant increase from 105 in the 2019 local elections, and it surpassed the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which maintained its 122 seats from 2019. The Alliance Party finished third, increasing its representation from 53 to 67 seats. The Ulster Unionist Party gained 54 seats, while the Social Democratic and Labour Party won 39 seats, with the remaining 36 seats shared among independents and other parties. A total of 807 candidates competed in the elections.

Sinn Féin clinched the most seats in six local councils, whereas the DUP remained the largest party in the other five. Northern Ireland councils are responsible for setting tax rates, planning development, and providing essential services such as waste disposal and public park maintenance.

According to the 1998 Good Friday Agreement, the largest nationalist and unionist parties must jointly form a government in semi-autonomous Northern Ireland. However, the government has been in limbo since DUP First Minister Paul Givan resigned in February 2022, refusing to participate thereafter. Givan resigned in opposition to checks imposed by the Northern Ireland Protocol on goods flowing from the rest of the UK to Northern Ireland, while the border with EU member Ireland remained unmonitored. In February, the UK and EU introduced the Windsor Framework to alleviate these trade checks, but the DUP rejected the proposal.

In the May 2022 elections for the Belfast-based Northern Ireland Assembly, Sinn Féin made history by overtaking the DUP to become the largest party for the first time. 

Sinn Féin's vice president, Michelle O'Neill, stated that the election represented a chance to convey a clear message in support of effective leadership and to push for the reestablishment of the Assembly. She urged joint efforts from the UK and Ireland to resolve the ongoing political stalemate.

DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson emphasized that they are seeking a mandate to negotiate amendments to the trade regulations, asserting, "This is about ensuring that Northern Ireland's ability to trade with the rest of the United Kingdom is respected and legally protected, restoring our place in the union."

content:

title: Coolum win tier 1 women’s cricket premiership on Australia’s Sunshine Coast
content:
Coolum secured the premiership in the top tier of women's cricket on Australia's Sunshine Coast on Sunday, defeating Hinterland by 83 runs in the Grand Final. Batting first, Coolum posted a strong total of 181 runs for the loss of 3 wickets in their allotted 30 overs.

In response, Hinterland managed to score only 98 runs, losing 8 wickets. Coolum captain Sammy Franks praised her team's performance, stating, "The girls played so well today. 181 with the bat, that's pretty solid [...] We aimed for 140, 150, but 181 was wonderful."

Following the match, two senior Coolum players, Kerry Cowling and Paula McKie, announced their retirement. Franks reflected on their contributions: "It was great to win and give Kezza and Paula a final farewell. Paula is retiring as well, and it was a little bit of a secret. title: US President Biden signals support for bill to repeal authorizations for use of military force against Iraq
content:
**Thursday, March 23, 2023**

On March 16, President Joe Biden expressed his support for a US Senate bill aimed at repealing the 1991 and 2002 authorizations for use of military force (AUMF) against Iraq. In a Statement of Administration Policy, Biden remarked that the bill, S. 316, would have "no impact" on current military operations, as none "rely primarily on the 2002 AUMF."

Truthout anticipates that the Senate will vote on S. 316 within the next week. If passed, the bill would eliminate the use of the 2002 AUMF as a legal basis for military actions both in and outside Iraq, which Truthout described as a "symbolic end" to US military involvement in the region. The 1991 and 2002 AUMFs initially authorized the Gulf and Iraq Wars, respectively, and multiple US presidents have since invoked the 2002 AUMF to justify military operations in Syria.

On June 17, 2021, the House of Representatives approved a repeal of the 2002 AUMF, but the bill did not advance in the Senate. Democratic Representative Gregory Meeks criticized the ongoing reliance on it, stating, "Repeal is crucial because the executive branch has a history of stretching the 2002 AUMF's legal authority." A resolution seeking to withdraw all US troops from Syria failed to pass the House on March 8.

Senate Bill S. 316 was introduced on February 9, has 45 cosponsors, and received approval from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by a 13–8 vote on March 8. Senator Mitt Romney, a Republican from Utah, commented to Insider, "The world continues to be a troubled place, and I don't want to remove any of the authorities that have been, or may be, relied upon to defend our interests." Florida Republican Senator Rick Scott similarly told Insider, "I don't want to do anything that reduces the President's ability to kill somebody like Soleimani," referencing the US's 2020 assassination of Qasem Soleimani, a top Iranian general.

In a CNN editorial on Saturday, US Representative Barbara Lee, a Democrat from California, and Bridget Moix, general secretary of the Quaker nonprofit Friends Committee on National Legislation, argued that by allowing the AUMFs to remain in force, Congress is neglecting its constitutional obligations. They stated, "[B]y allowing the authorization to remain on the books, lawmakers in Congress are also abdicating a core constitutional responsibility. Our nation’s founders vested Congress with the sole power to decide when and where our country goes to war, and this power was granted for good reason: They knew that in a democratic system of checks and balances, no one person should have unilateral say over matters of war and peace." Representative Lee was the only lawmaker to vote against the 2001 AUMF that authorized military action in Afghanistan after the September 11 attacks.

title: African Union summit closes; bloc reaffirms member suspensions, support for trade deal
content:
**Thursday, February 23, 2023**

The African Union (AU) concluded its annual summit on Sunday after two days of discussions in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. Leaders reaffirmed their commitment to maintain the suspensions of four AU member nations and to "accelerate the implementation" of the African Continental Free Trade Agreement (AfCFTA).

The suspended nations—Burkina Faso, Guinea, Mali, and Sudan—are currently under military governance following recent coups. Bankole Adeoye, the AU's Commissioner for Political Affairs, Peace and Security, emphasized the organization's "zero tolerance" policy towards coups while expressing readiness to assist these countries in returning to constitutional order.

Initiated in 2020, the AfCFTA has faced challenges due to disagreements over tariff reductions and border closures related to the COVID-19 pandemic. All 55 African nations, excluding Eritrea, are members of its associated product, the African Continental Free Trade Area, touted as the world's largest free-trade area by population. Currently, just 15% of trade in Africa occurs between African nations, a figure the AfCFTA aims to elevate to 60% by 2034.

On Sunday, the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) announced it will continue to enforce strict trade restrictions and sanctions against Mali, with similar measures—though to a lesser extent—applied to Guinea and Burkina Faso. Additionally, ECOWAS will impose travel bans on leaders and officials from these countries. The organization is advocating for a return to civilian governance by 2024 in Burkina Faso and Mali, and by 2025 in Guinea.

title: Reports: 'streamlined' UK asylum process to replace interview with questionnaire for five nationalities
content:
**Thursday, February 23, 2023**

The UK Home Office announced today that it will start issuing questionnaires instead of conducting official interviews to assess refugee status for approximately 12,000 asylum seekers from Afghanistan, Eritrea, Libya, Syria, and Yemen who applied before last summer. This initiative is part of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's plan to address the nation’s backlog of 92,000 asylum claims by the end of the year.

While standard security, criminal, and health checks will still be conducted, the face-to-face interview requirement will be eliminated to "streamline" processing for these five nationalities, which have a claim acceptance rate exceeding 95%. The questionnaires range from 10 to 32 pages and include 40 to 50 questions. They must be completed in English, with the government advising the use of "online translation tools" if necessary, and returned within twenty working days. According to a leaked internal letter reviewed by Sky News, failure to return the questionnaire without a reasonable explanation may lead to the withdrawal of the asylum claim, though the government will issue a reminder after the deadline and consider extensions.

Officials indicated to BBC News that all claims will be assessed on their merits, and the i reported that no one will be denied solely based on the questionnaire responses. A similar fast-track system for 3,000 Afghan refugees, supported by the British Red Cross in September 2021, was reportedly rejected by Prime Minister Boris Johnson over concerns it could be seen as amnesty, an assertion the Home Office disputes, along with worries it could strain welfare and housing resources.

Labour's Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper expressed her party's support for such measures "for months," criticizing the Home Office for not implementing this approach sooner, especially for safe countries like Albania, after the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees recommended it two years ago. She stated, "Labour has a common-sense plan to fast-track cases, establish return agreements for unsuccessful claims, and take stronger action against criminal gangs involved in dangerous small boat crossings."

Figures released today show that a record 45,756 migrants crossed the Channel last year, pushing outstanding asylum claims to over 150,000, also a record. Sunak has prioritized migration issues, with new laws expected next month that ban illegal migrants from claiming asylum in the UK. The Home Office letter indicated that the use of questionnaires might expand to include other claimants awaiting asylum decisions in the future, though no current plans for such an expansion exist.

On Wednesday, Home Secretary Suella Braverman commented on GB News that the current situation regarding illegal arrivals is "unsustainable" and burdensome on local communities. However, the introduction of questionnaires has drawn criticism for potentially easing the process for some asylum seekers and imposing challenges for those who may not speak English or lack access to assistance or legal counsel.

The Guardian highlighted some complicated questions in the forms with intricate language, such as: "Were you subject to human trafficking or modern slavery during your journey to or after your arrival in the UK?" Critics like immigration barrister Colin Yeo and Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants campaigner Caitlin Boswell have voiced concerns. Boswell noted, "People fleeing desperate circumstances need quicker and fairer asylum decisions, but this government’s approach is clumsy and could jeopardize their safety. No one’s right to refuge should be at risk because they struggled to complete a lengthy form in a language they do not understand."

Following the leak, CEO of the Refugee Council Enver Solomon told Sky News that any changes to the process "must be well thought out." He welcomed efforts to reduce the backlog but argued against creating more bureaucratic hurdles and threats to withdraw applications. "It is not fair or reasonable to expect people who have lived in uncertainty for months or years to complete a lengthy form in English within a few weeks, especially when they lack legal support and English proficiency."

During Prime Minister’s Questions on Wednesday, Sunak defended the government's approach while promising a forthcoming "formal update" from Braverman, stating, "The Home Secretary and I are working diligently to advance this legislation. In the meantime, our agreements with Albania and France are already yielding results. We aim to create a system in which individuals arriving in our country illegally will not be permitted to stay."

title: US condemns Russian Defense Minister for awarding pilots who intercepted US drone
content:
**Friday, March 24, 2023**

During a press briefing on Wednesday, White House National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby criticized Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu for awarding the Order of Courage to two Russian pilots who intercepted a U.S. MQ-9 Reaper drone over the Black Sea. 

Kirby remarked, “I’m not aware of any other military in the world that would honor a pilot for colliding with a drone. If that’s considered bravery, then their criteria differ significantly. It’s absurd and offensive. We can't determine if the pilot intended to ram the drone, but the video evidence is quite clear.”

On March 14, the United States Air Forces in Europe – Air Forces Africa (USAFE-AFAFRICA) reported that the incident took place at 07:03 CET (06:03 UTC) over international waters, identifying the Russian aircraft involved as Sukhoi Su-27s. 

U.S. Air Force General James B. Hecker, commander of USAFE-AFAFRICA, stated: “Before the collision, the Su-27s engaged in reckless and environmentally damaging behavior by dumping fuel and flying directly in front of the MQ-9.”

U.S. State Department spokesperson Ned Price, commenting on the incident on MSNBC on March 15, suggested, “Our best assessment is that the crash was likely unintentional and might stem from significant incompetence on the part of the Russian pilot.”

The following day, the United States European Command (EUCOM) declassified a 42-second video clip from the incident, which showed two passes made over the drone. After the second pass, which EUCOM claims resulted in a collision, the footage cuts out briefly before returning to reveal damage to the drone's propeller. The MQ-9's operators intentionally crashed the drone into the sea, citing the damaged propeller as the cause.

Russia has denied responsibility for bringing down the drone or that a Russian jet made contact, asserting that the drone's "sharp maneuvering" caused its crash. Samir Puri, a visiting lecturer in war studies at King's College London, informed Al Jazeera that while the video does not establish intent, it is likely that Russian pilots operate aggressively to display their dominance over the skies, suggesting that Americans cannot conduct intelligence flights unchallenged.

Nikolai Patrushev, secretary of the Security Council of Russia, asserted, “The Americans consistently claim they are not involved in military operations. This incident is further evidence of their direct involvement in these activities— in the war.”

The Guardian speculated that the incident could escalate tensions related to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. There was some confusion in media reports regarding when Shoigu presented the awards, with CNN and Insider stating it occurred on March 17, while Sputnik and The Hill reported that it happened on Wednesday.

Shoigu's Ministry of Defense claimed the pilots “prevented the violation of airspace boundaries established for the special military operation by the American MQ-9 unmanned aerial vehicle.”

title: Expedition locates wreck of World War II-sunk ship Montevideo Maru
content:
**Monday, April 24, 2023**

On Saturday (Friday UTC), Australian Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles announced on Twitter that a team from the Australia-based Silentworld Foundation had located the wreck of the Montevideo Maru in the South China Sea. The ship, a Japanese merchant vessel, was transporting prisoners of war (POWs) when it was torpedoed by the United States Navy in 1942 during World War II, resulting in the deaths of 1,080 individuals.

The wreckage was discovered at a depth of over 4,000 meters (13,123 ft) northwest of Luzon, Philippines, surpassing the depth of the RMS Titanic wreck. The Silentworld team, in collaboration with deep-sea specialists from Dutch company Fugro and supported by the Department of Defence, conducted a twelve-day search around Luzon utilizing an unmanned underwater vehicle equipped with sonar technology.

On July 1, 1942, POWs captured in Rabaul, Papua New Guinea, were being transported aboard the Montevideo Maru to Hainan, which was under Japanese occupation. The POWs included civilians and military personnel from fourteen countries, with 864 being Australian Army troops. The Montevideo Maru was not marked as carrying POWs, leading a United States Navy submarine to fire torpedoes at the ship, resulting in its sinking.

The Silentworld Foundation noted that no plans were in place to recover human remains from the Montevideo Maru; however, they are considering commemorative events for July 1, the anniversary of the sinking. 

"This brings to an end one of the most tragic chapters in Australia's maritime history," Marles stated. "[Knowing] the location of this wreck provides comfort and relief to so many Australian families."

Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese remarked, "The extraordinary effort behind this discovery speaks to the enduring truth of Australia's solemn national promise to always remember and honor those who served our country."

Lieutenant General Simon Stuart added, "I want to thank the Silentworld team and the dedicated researchers, including the Unrecovered War Casualties team at Army, who have never given up hope of finding the final resting place of the Montevideo Maru. A loss like this resonates through the decades and reminds us all of the human cost of conflict. Lest we forget."

title: US political commentator Tucker Carlson, Fox News separate
content:
**Monday, April 24, 2023**

Fox Media announced today that Tucker Carlson is no longer with the company. Carlson had been the host of Tucker Carlson Tonight, a cable prime time talk show on Fox News, since 2016, with the last episode airing on Friday.

A spokesperson for Fox Media expressed gratitude for his contributions, stating, "We thank him for his service to the network as a host." Carlson's program will be replaced by a new show, Fox News Tonight, which will feature various hosts.

This announcement comes shortly after Fox News reached a settlement in a defamation lawsuit filed by Dominion Voting Systems, agreeing to pay $787.5 million in damages. The network has not clarified whether the settlement influenced Carlson's departure.

The Dominion lawsuit focused on Fox News' assertions that the 2020 U.S. presidential election was fraudulent. In a court document related to the settlement, Fox acknowledged the court's findings that certain claims about Dominion were false.

Dominion had also obtained messages from group chats involving Carlson, Sean Hannity, and Laura Ingraham, in which Carlson expressed a strong dislike for then-President Donald Trump.

title: British Academy of Film and Television Arts announces recipients of 2023 Film Awards
content:
On Sunday, February 25, 2023, the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) held its 2023 Film Awards ceremony at London’s Royal Festival Hall. 

The German anti-war film *All Quiet on the Western Front* emerged as the night’s big winner, taking home seven out of its fourteen nominations, including Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Direction, and Best Film. *The Banshees of Inisherin* was awarded Outstanding British Film and Best Original Screenplay. Additionally, the film adaptation of *The Boy, the Mole, the Fox and the Horse* won the award for Best British Short Animation.

*Avatar: The Way of Water* received the Award for Best Special Visual Effects. Cate Blanchett won Best Actress in a Leading Role for her performance in *Tár*, while Austin Butler took home Best Actor in a Leading Role for *Elvis*. Emma Mackey was honored with the EE Rising Star Award.

Sandy Powell, the acclaimed costume designer, received the BAFTA Fellowship for lifetime achievement. 

CNN described *All Quiet on the Western Front* as "the sweeping victor of the night." Producer Malte Grunert expressed his gratitude, stating, "We’ve been blessed with so many nominations and winning this is just incredible." Mackey shared her pride in being nominated, calling the win "really special."

title: EU agrees €43 billion Chips Act to boost semiconductor production
content:
**Sunday, April 23, 2023**

On Tuesday, the European Council, representing member states, reached an agreement with the European Parliament on an initiative aimed at strengthening the European Union (EU) semiconductor industry and reducing dependence on Asian suppliers. 

Originally proposed by the European Commission last year to focus solely on subsidizing the production of cutting-edge chips, the funding will now encompass facilities across the entire value chain, including support for older chips and research and design.

The agreement aims to raise over €43 billion from both public and private sources to finance the subsidies, with the ultimate goal of quadrupling production and increasing the EU's share of the semiconductor market to 20% by 2030.

The Swedish presidency of the Council of the European Union remarked, "The Chips Act will enhance the European ecosystem for semiconductors and play a crucial role in strengthening the EU's global competitiveness."

The EU has emphasized the importance of domestic chip production in response to supply chain disruptions after the pandemic and as part of a broader strategy to reduce vulnerability to global shocks, particularly following the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has prompted member states to reduce their reliance on Russian gas.

In a statement after the agreement, Internal Markets Commissioner Thierry Breton noted, "This will enable us to rebalance and secure our supply chains, lessening our collective dependence on Asia." Currently, Asian companies, particularly those in China and Taiwan, dominate global chip manufacturing and exportation.

This initiative follows the United States’ commitment last August to invest approximately $52 billion in microchip manufacturing and additional funding for research and development, along with similar production-enhancing pledges from Japan and South Korea.

title: Prisoner exchange in Yemen ends after freeing over 800
content:
**Sunday, April 23, 2023**

On April 16, the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) announced the successful completion of a United Nations-brokered exchange of 869 prisoners between the Aden-based government and the Houthi government amid the ongoing Yemeni civil war. 

ICRC flights began transporting prisoners among Houthi-controlled areas, Aden, and Saudi Arabian cities starting on April 14. According to the Associated Press, more than 700 of the prisoners were Houthis, while others included Saudi and Sudanese soldiers from the Saudi-led coalition supporting the Aden government.

Among those released to the Aden government were four journalists facing execution by the Houthis, Major General and former Defense Minister Mahmoud al-Subaihi, and Nasser Mansur Hadi, the brother of former President Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi.

In a separate operation, the coalition released 104 Houthi prisoners of war via ICRC flights on Monday, with 96 arriving in Houthi-controlled Sana'a and eight landing in Aden.

Negotiations held in March near Bern, Switzerland, led to this prisoner exchange and an agreement for further discussions in May. The United Nations-brokered Stockholm Agreement facilitated previous conferences that resulted in similar prisoner swaps in 2020 and last year.

Additionally, the Houthis hosted Saudi representatives for peace talks in Sana'a, which continued through Thursday.

The civil war in Yemen, which began in 2014, is now largely viewed as a proxy conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran, according to reports from Reuters and the Associated Press.

title: Authorities charge former guard with sexually assaulting 13 prisoners at Central California Women's Facility
content:
**Friday, May 26, 2023**

On Wednesday, police in Madera County, California, arrested retired corrections officer Gregory Rodriguez, setting his bail at $7.8 million for allegedly sexually assaulting 13 inmates at the Central California Women's Facility in Chowchilla. 

Rodriguez faces 96 charges, which include rape, sodomy, oral copulation, and sexual battery, related to a total of 39 alleged sexual assaults. If convicted, he could face more than 300 years in prison.

The District Attorney's Office reported that the earliest allegations date back to 2014, with the majority arising in the last two years. The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation initiated an investigation into Rodriguez in July and submitted its findings in December, estimating that he may have committed sexual misconduct against more than 22 individuals.

title: China summons Japan's ambassador over G7's statements
content:
**Revised News Article**  
**Date: Friday, May 26, 2023**

On Sunday, China's Foreign Ministry summoned the Japanese ambassador to China, Hideo Tarumi, to express its discontent over what it termed the "hype surrounding China-related issues." This diplomatic tension follows comments made by the Group of 7 (G7) during their meeting in Hiroshima, Japan, which addressed topics Beijing considers internal affairs.

Vice Foreign Minister Sun Weidong conveyed China's "strong dissatisfaction and resolute opposition" to the statements made by the G7. He accused Japan, as the chair of the G7 summit, of collaborating with other nations to "smear and attack China" and asserted that such actions severely interfere in China's internal matters, infringe upon international law, and violate the spirit of key political agreements between China and Japan, including the 1972 Japan—China Joint Statement.

In response, Tarumi's office characterized the G7's comments as "only natural" concerning mutual interests and suggested that if China prefers these issues not to be highlighted, it should adopt a more constructive approach.

While the G7 leaders expressed their concerns about China's actions, they emphasized that their policy measures are not intended to harm China or impede its economic development. They reiterated their commitment against decoupling and maintaining an open approach.

Sun further stated that Taiwan, which China refers to as a breakaway province and has not ruled out military action to reclaim, constitutes "the core of China's core interests" and stressed that it represents a "red line that must not be crossed." The G7 criticized China's military activities in the South China Sea and affirmed the necessity of "peace and stability" in the Taiwan Strait for global security.

The G7 also accused China of using economic coercion in international disputes and announced plans to "reduce excessive dependencies on China within critical supply chains." Additionally, they condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with Moscow labeling the summit an "incubator" for hostility towards itself and its ally, China.

On Monday, Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary, Hirokazu Matsuno, reiterated that Japan's stance on China remains consistent, focusing on cooperation on shared concerns while advocating for responsible actions. 

Moritz Rudolf, a scholar at Yale University’s Paul Tsai China Center, noted that "Beijing's swift reaction highlights the already heightened tensions in the region, which are likely to escalate further."

title: Strongest tornado since 1983 strikes Los Angeles County, California
content:
**Monday, March 27, 2023**

On Wednesday, a tornado struck Los Angeles County, California, resulting in minor injuries to one person and damaging at least 17 buildings, according to the National Weather Service. The tornado, classified as EF-1, had peak winds of 110 miles per hour (177 kilometers per hour) and touched down in Montebello, marking the county's most severe tornado since 1983.

The National Weather Service reported that as the tornado moved into Los Angeles, it wreaked havoc on vehicles, destroyed skylights, caved in a building's roof, snapped a utility pole, and uprooted a pine tree with a trunk nearly a foot wide.

On Tuesday, an EF-0 tornado caused damage to 25 mobile homes in Carpinteria, California, located in Santa Barbara County, and also inflicted minor damage to trees in a nearby cemetery, according to National Weather Service personnel.

Tornadoes are relatively rare in California, with the state averaging fewer than 10 to 11 annually. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration also noted that these tornadoes rarely gain significant strength or longevity.

In recent months, California has experienced severe weather, including flooding and at least 12 atmospheric rivers, which have brought flooding and hurricane-force winds to the region. A storm in the San Francisco area on Tuesday resulted in at least five fatalities and caused over 700 trees and limbs, as well as power lines, to be downed. Residents reported incidents of high-rise buildings shedding glass and other debris.

title: Canadian soldier who filmed himself sexually abusing colleague has appeal dismissed
content:
**Sunday, February 26, 2023**

On February 17, the Supreme Court of Canada unanimously dismissed an appeal by former Corporal Colin McGregor, ruling 8-0 that the investigation leading to his 2019 conviction for sexual assault did not violate the Charter of Rights and Freedoms regarding reasonable search and seizure.

This decision brings an end to McGregor's prolonged legal battle as the court characterized the police investigation of his residence in the United States as "reasonable pursuant to Charter standards."

McGregor was found guilty on September 30, 2019, of two counts of voyeurism, one count of possessing a device for surreptitious interception of private communications, one count of sexual assault, and one count of disgraceful conduct related to incidents occurring between 2011 and 2017. He received a three-year prison sentence from a military judge at Canadian Forces Base Esquimalt in British Columbia, was placed on the sex offender registry for twenty years, and was dismissed from the Armed Forces with disgrace.

Following last Friday's ruling, McGregor's sentence remains intact, and upon his release, he will be prohibited from future employment with the Canadian government.

From August 2015 to March 2017, McGregor was stationed at the Canadian Defence Liaison Staff at Canada's US embassy, which granted him diplomatic immunity. In January 2017, a fellow Canadian Armed Forces member in Washington, D.C., discovered two audio recording devices in her home, leading her to suspect McGregor. She reported him to her superior officer, prompting an investigation that involved the Embassy waiving his diplomatic immunity at the request of the Canadian Forces National Investigation Service (CFNIS).

On February 16, 2017, CFNIS agents, along with local Virginia police, executed a search warrant at McGregor's staff quarters in Alexandria, Virginia, seizing various electronic devices including computers, CDs, storage devices, and five hidden cameras. Forensic analysis revealed disturbing evidence, including a video from 2011 showing McGregor groping an unconscious woman in Victoria, as well as recordings of another woman in a compromising situation. Charges related to child pornography concerning other recordings were later dropped.

The woman featured in the video testified in court that the footage was taken after she invited McGregor over for drinks and video games, stating she blacked out and awoke to find him sexually assaulting her.

title: 'Let's finish this job': US President Joe Biden announces 2024 reelection bid
content:
**Thursday, April 27, 2023**

On Tuesday, President Joe Biden announced his candidacy for reelection in 2024, marking the launch of his campaign exactly four years after his 2020 announcement. In a three-minute video, Biden emphasized the theme of personal freedom, stating, "Freedom. Personal freedom is fundamental to who we are as Americans. There's nothing more important. Nothing more sacred." As images of the January 6 Capitol attack and abortion rights protests flashed across the screen, he warned about the dangers of "MAGA [Make America Great Again] extremists" seeking to undermine essential freedoms.

Biden spotlighted key issues, stating, "Cutting Social Security that you've paid for your entire life while cutting taxes for the very wealthy. Dictating what healthcare decisions women can make, banning books, and telling people whom they can love. All while making it more difficult for you to vote." Amid a montage featuring himself, Vice President Kamala Harris, his first term, and prominent Republican figures like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis, he reiterated, "When I ran for president four years ago, I said we are in a battle for the soul of America. And we still are."

Expressing urgency, he declared, "This is not a time to be complacent. That's why I'm running for reelection. This is our moment to defend democracy, stand up for our personal freedoms, and finish this job. I know we can." During his first campaign event, Biden applauded job growth in the construction industry while addressing members of North America’s Building Trades Unions, rallying support with the chant, “Let’s Go Joe.” He affirmed his administration's commitment to being "the most pro-union administration in American history."

In the Democratic primary, candidates already in the race include author and spiritual advisor Marianne Williamson and Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a member of the Kennedy family. Former President Trump has also begun his campaign to reclaim the presidency after losing to Biden in 2020. 

Former President Barack Obama expressed support for Biden's campaign, sharing the launch video on social media and praising the accomplishments of Biden's administration, stating, “He’s delivered for the American people — and he’ll continue to do so once he’s re-elected. Let’s get to work!”

Republican National Committee Chair Ronna McDaniel criticized Biden's bid for a second term, arguing that his presidency has led to numerous crises. She stated, “If voters let Biden 'finish the job,' inflation will continue to skyrocket, crime rates will rise, and American families will be worse off.” An RNC advertisement even employed artificial intelligence to suggest a dire future under another Biden term.

Pro-Trump super PAC Make America Great Again, Inc. released a statement asserting, “America is on the brink of a deadly nuclear war,” labeling Biden's presidency a failure and urging voters to choose a different path in 2024.

During a rally at her alma mater, Howard University, Vice President Harris emphasized abortion rights, asserting confidence in American women and their choices, and framing her reelection campaign as part of a mission to "finish the job."

Democratic strategist Jeff Link highlighted concerns about Biden's age and the necessity for him to present himself as engaged and focused on working families. He noted, “Folks are still concerned about the threat that Trump poses,” and emphasized the importance of a second Biden term in maintaining that barrier.

In his February State of the Union address, Biden frequently used the phrase “let’s finish the job,” framing his administration's goals against the backdrop of potential Republican opposition, including cuts to critical programs.

Current polling reveals Biden's approval rating at 40%, with a 56% disapproval rating. This marks a decline compared to the beginning of his last campaign, where he enjoyed a 53% approval rating. Additionally, as the nation grapples with inflation levels not seen in decades, an NBC News poll found that 70% of Americans and 51% of Democrats do not believe Biden should seek reelection. Concerns about his age are significant, with many Democrats voicing skepticism regarding his fitness for office. Biden, at 80, is the oldest president in U.S. history, acknowledging such concerns as “totally legitimate” while challenging voters to “watch me.”

Biden’s physician deemed him "healthy, vigorous," and "fit" for the presidency following a physical examination in February. His press secretary, Karine Jean-Pierre, was unable to confirm whether Biden would serve a full second term if re-elected, but later tweeted assurance that he would serve all eight years.

First Lady Jill Biden expressed her support for her husband's reelection campaign, while Biden acknowledged that his recent trip to Ireland solidified his commitment to run again. 

Biden has appointed Julie Chávez Rodriguez as his campaign manager and Quentin Fulks as deputy campaign manager, marking experienced leaders to guide his efforts. The campaign also announced co-chairs, including U.S. Representatives Lisa Blunt Rochester, Jim Clyburn, and Veronica Escobar, along with Senators Chris Coons and Tammy Duckworth, and Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer.

title: Moldova denies Russian allegations of Ukrainian plan to attack breakaway Transnistria
content:
**Monday, February 27, 2023**

Moldovan officials on Thursday refuted Russia's allegation that Ukraine is planning an attack on Transnistria, a breakaway region internationally recognized as part of Moldova. MP Doina Gherman characterized the Russian claims as "aggressive disinformation," while Secretary of State Valeriu Mija described the statement as a "psychological operation" rather than a "real plan."

The Moldovan government, via its Telegram channel, urged citizens to remain calm and to rely on "information from official and credible sources of the Republic of Moldova."

The Russian Ministry of Defence had earlier claimed that Ukraine was gathering a "significant amount of personnel and military vehicles" near the Transnistria border in preparation for an alleged invasion, which it asserted posed "a direct threat" to Russian troops stationed in the breakaway region. The Ministry added that "the armed forces of the Russian Federation will adequately respond to the impending provocation from the Ukrainian side."

A separatist social media account claimed to have evidence of a Ukrainian military buildup, though it only shared an image featuring a Ukrainian flag and a few small armored vehicles.

For weeks, Moldova, which leans towards the West, has expressed concerns about a potential coup plot by Russia. On February 22, Russia reversed a 2012 decree recognizing Moldova's sovereignty, raising further alarm within the small nation.

Transnistria, which is predominantly Russian-speaking, declared independence from Moldova in 1990, leading to a two-year conflict. Since the war's conclusion, Russia has stationed approximately 1,500 peacekeepers in Transnistria.

title: US President Biden nominates former Mastercard chief Ajay Banga for World Bank president
content:
**Monday, February 27, 2023**  

On Thursday, President Joe Biden nominated Ajay S. Banga to serve as the next president of the World Bank. This nomination coincides with increasing pressure from the US for the bank to prioritize climate change initiatives.  

Banga, 63, is an Indian-American businessman known for his tenure as CEO of Mastercard, where he led the company for over a decade. Following his retirement from Mastercard, he took on the role of vice chairman at the private equity firm General Atlantic.  

"Ajay is uniquely equipped to lead the World Bank at this critical moment in history," Biden stated.  

World Bank officials indicated on Wednesday that a new president to succeed incumbent David Malpass is expected to be announced by early May. Malpass, who recently announced his resignation, faced ongoing criticism regarding his stance on climate change. According to Reuters, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged Malpass to implement "bolder and more innovative" changes.  

Furthermore, Germany has expressed that the World Bank should be led by a woman, noting that no woman has held the position in the institution's 77-year history.  

While Banga's nomination is the first to be made public, the nomination period for World Bank member countries remains open until March 29.

title: US singer Madonna's elder brother Anthony Ciccone dies at age 66
content:
**Monday, February 27, 2023**

On Friday, Anthony Ciccone, the older brother of US singer Madonna, passed away at the age of 66. The cause of death has not yet been disclosed. 

Ciccone's brother-in-law, Joe Henry, announced the news on Instagram, describing him as a “complex character.” He expressed hope that a divine figure, as believed by their mother, was there to welcome Ciccone. "At least for today, no one shall dissuade me from this vision," he wrote.

Madonna acknowledged Henry's post with a "like," but has not made a public statement regarding her brother's passing. 

Madonna, Anthony, and their six siblings were raised in Detroit, Michigan. When Madonna moved to New York City in 1978 to pursue her music career, Ciccone chose to stay behind. He later faced challenges, including estrangement from his family, alcoholism, and periods of homelessness. However, by 2017, he had completed a rehabilitation program and reconciled with his family.

title: G20 fails to agree on joint statement on Russian invasion of Ukraine
content:
**Tuesday, February 28, 2023**

Finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Twenty (G20) concluded a two-day meeting in Bengaluru, India, on Saturday without reaching a consensus on a joint statement. Russia and China objected to a proposed condemnation of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

As the host, India was cautious about addressing the war, emphasizing its neutral stance and preference for a diplomatic resolution. However, Western nations insisted that a joint agreement must include a condemnation of Russia's actions. 

In lieu of a joint statement, India released a "chair's summary and outcome document," which noted that "most members strongly condemned the war in Ukraine," highlighting its severe humanitarian impact and adverse effects on the global economy, including growth constraints, rising inflation, supply chain disruptions, and increased energy and food insecurity.

The summary also acknowledged differing perspectives on the situation and sanctions, stating, "Recognising that the G20 is not the forum to resolve security issues, we acknowledge that security issues can have significant consequences for the global economy." A footnote clarified that the description of the war was "agreed to by all member countries except Russia and China."

Ajay Seth, a senior Indian official, explained in a press conference that representatives from Russia and China believed their focus should remain on economic and financial matters, opposed to including the Ukrainian conflict in any statement. He added, "On the other hand, all the other 18 countries felt that the war has got implications for the global economy."

The summit also addressed issues of debt relief for developing nations and cryptocurrency regulation. According to Reuters, there is increasing pressure on creditor nations, including China—the largest bilateral creditor—to reduce the debt burden faced by struggling countries. 

Chinese Finance Minister Liu Kun reiterated that multilateral development banks, including the World Bank, should also consider debt reductions to help alleviate the challenges faced by these countries. 

India's push for stricter cryptocurrency regulations received broad support. On Saturday, International Monetary Fund (IMF) Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva and Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman co-hosted a meeting regarding debt restructuring, attended by representatives from the World Bank, China, India, Saudi Arabia, and G7 member nations. 

US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen described this gathering as organizational and noted that no "deliverables" were produced. Georgieva stated, "We just finished a session in which it was clear that there is a commitment to bridge differences for the benefit of countries." She emphasized that policymakers should not dismiss the possibility of outright bans if regulations prove ineffective, while Yellen advocated for establishing a strong regulatory framework.

Sitharaman highlighted the challenges faced by Ethiopia, Ghana, Sri Lanka, and Zambia, stating, "Strengthening multilateral coordination by official bilateral and private creditors is needed to address the deteriorating debt situation and facilitate coordinated debt treatment for debt-distressed countries." 

At the G20's November meeting in Bali, Indonesia issued a Leaders' Declaration instead of a communiqué after similar disagreements on the invasion of Ukraine.

title: UN agency reports 531 dead in Haiti, calls for international support
content:
**Tuesday, March 28, 2023**

The United Nations Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights called on the international community on March 21 to "urgently consider the deployment of a time-bound specialized support force" to Haiti, as gang violence has resulted in 531 deaths since the beginning of the year. 

Spokesperson Marta Hurtado expressed that "clashes between gangs are becoming more violent and more frequent," voicing "grave concern" over the deteriorating security situation. She reported that these gang confrontations have led to at least 208 deaths, 164 injuries, and 101 kidnappings in the first two weeks of March alone. Hurtado emphasized that "most of the victims were killed or injured by snipers reportedly shooting randomly at people in their homes or on the streets."

Hurtado also highlighted the alarming trend of armed gangs forcibly recruiting children, linking this to the loss of protection due to school closures. She noted that half of the population is facing food insecurity as food prices soar, with over 160,000 Haitians living in precarious conditions, a quarter of whom are in makeshift shelters with limited access to sanitation.

The call for a support force has gained international traction since Haitian Prime Minister Ariel Henry first requested assistance in October, according to The Guardian, amidst a backdrop of past failed foreign interventions in Haiti. The report indicated that the U.S. has approached Brazil to lead such a force. Brazil previously co-led a peacekeeping mission in Haiti from 2004 to 2017; Foreign Minister Mauro Vieira commented earlier this year, "I think we need to seek other solutions – I don’t know if sending troops or a peacekeeping operation is the solution."

As reported by Agence France-Presse (AFP), a political and economic crisis has been escalating in Haiti since the assassination of President Jovenel Moise in July 2021, which ignited infighting among politicians. The AFP also noted school closures due to the perilous environment, which has seen students, teachers, and parents caught in crossfire and targeted for kidnappings.

UN Secretary-General António Guterres advocated for the establishment of a "rapid action force" to support the Haitian police in 2022. During a visit to Haiti last month, UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk described the situation as a "living hell," revealing that "twenty thousand people are in a catastrophic, famine-like situation." Türk urged Haitian officials to reinforce the police force and implement judicial reforms to tackle the ongoing security challenges.

title: Reports: US judge Matthew Kacsmaryk redacted name of corporation he owned stock in on disclosure forms
content:
**Friday, April 28, 2023**

An investigation by CNN, published on April 21, revealed that the name of a corporation in which United States District Court Judge Matthew J. Kacsmaryk of the Northern District of Texas owned stock was redacted in his 2020 and 2021 financial disclosures. The Washington Post also reported on these redactions.

In 2021, more than 85% of Kacsmaryk's reported wealth was derived from this holding, which is valued between $5 million and $25 million. 

Michael Lissner, executive director of the Free Law Project, told CNN, "If you have stock and you're not disclosing what it is, especially when it constitutes such a significant portion of your personal wealth, that's a conflict. The public deserves to know." 

Kacsmaryk, in a response to CNN, explained that the redaction was authorized by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts and indicated that the entity in question was a non-Texas private corporation. He added, "The Clerk's Office has the name of the entity, actively screens incoming cases, and I would be automatically recused from any cases involving this entity."

Earlier this month, Kacsmaryk suspended the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's approval of the abortion pill mifepristone, which barred consumers from accessing it. However, on Friday, the U.S. Supreme Court issued a stay of that suspension.

These revelations followed an investigation by ProPublica that examined Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas's failure to disclose vacations and property sales involving a billionaire described by the nonprofit as a conservative.

title: US National Park Service announces part of Yosemite National Park to close for days as flooding forecast
content:
**Friday, April 28, 2023**

On Tuesday, the National Park Service (NPS) announced that the eastern section of Yosemite Valley in Yosemite National Park, California, will be closed to visitors from 10:00 PM PDT (UTC−07:00) on Friday through at least Wednesday due to anticipated flooding. 

According to the park service's Yosemite Instagram account, areas such as Wawona, Mariposa Grove and its trails, Crane Flat, Hetch Hetchy, and the western Yosemite Valley will remain open. 

Scott Gediman, a spokesperson for Yosemite, indicated that the closure could extend into June or July. The NPS typically restricts access to parts of the park when the Merced River is expected to exceed 10 feet (3 m) above normal, as this is when roads and other vital infrastructure may begin to flood.

The National Weather Service forecasted temperatures this weekend to be 10°F (5.5°C) to 12°F (6.5°C) above average, which is expected to accelerate snowmelt. This winter's snowpack has reached a record high, estimated at 240% above average. "I've been in Yosemite for 27 years, and I've never seen this much snow," Gediman remarked, noting that some areas received as much as 15 feet (5 m) of snow in February.

title: 'I'm tired, extremely tired': Western Australia Premier Mark McGowan announces resignation
content:
**Tuesday, May 30, 2023**

Western Australia Premier and Treasurer Mark McGowan announced his retirement during a press conference yesterday, marking the end of his six-year tenure as premier and 26 years as the Member for Rockingham. 

As the leader of the Labor Party, McGowan expressed, "The truth is I'm tired, extremely tired. In fact, I'm exhausted." He added, "It has been an honour and privilege to serve the people of the state in my community over this time. It is way beyond what I could ever have imagined my career would amount to. WA [Western Australia] has provided me with the opportunity of a lifetime."

In a Facebook post, McGowan reflected on his time in office, saying, "I've loved the role. I've loved being able to deliver on our agenda for the benefit of our State and I've loved the challenge of solving problems, making decisions, getting outcomes, and helping people."

Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese praised McGowan's leadership, stating, "He has been a great Premier of his proud state, an extraordinary leader for WA Labor and a trusted friend. In unprecedented times, Mark always held to his convictions and always sought to do the right thing by his state."

Albanese revealed that McGowan had informed him of his decision to step down earlier on Monday. Under McGowan's leadership, the COVID-19 pandemic boosted his approval rating to 91%, and in the 2021 state election, Labor secured 53 of 59 lower-chamber seats. McGowan's resignation will prompt the Labor Party to select a new leader ahead of the upcoming state election scheduled for 2025.

title: Actor Alan Cumming returns OBE for British Empire's 'toxicity'
content:
**Monday, January 30, 2023**

On Friday, Scottish actor and producer Alan Cumming announced that the historical impact of the British Empire, which he described as having profited "at the expense (and death) of indigenous peoples around the world," led him to decide to return the OBE he received in 2009. 

In a post on Instagram marking his 58th birthday, the two-time Tony Award winner shared that his concerns about being linked to "the toxicity of empire" overshadowed the "great good" associated with receiving the honor, which he had previously viewed as a symbol of support for the LGBT community.

Cumming was awarded the chivalric honor, or "Order of the British Empire," as part of Queen Elizabeth II's Birthday Honours for his work as an actor and activist advocating for equal rights for the gay and lesbian community. A US citizen since 2008, Cumming has been a vocal critic of the now-repealed Defense of Marriage Act, which denied federal recognition of same-sex marriage, as well as the 'don't ask, don't tell' policy that barred openly LGBT individuals from serving in the US Armed Forces.

At the time of receiving the OBE, he remarked, "I see this honour as encouragement to go on fighting for what I believe is right and for what I take for granted as a UK citizen. Thank you to the Queen and those who make up her birthday honours list for bringing attention to the inaction of the US government on this issue. It makes me very proud to be British, and galvanised as an American."

However, following the repeal of those laws and the discussions surrounding the role of the monarchy and the legacy of British colonialism that arose after Elizabeth II's death in September, Cumming felt that "the great good the award brought to the LGBTQ+ cause back in 2009 is now less potent than the misgivings I have being associated with the toxicity of empire."

Historically, other celebrities have also returned OBEs in protest of social issues. For example, in 2020, Welsh actor Michael Sheen announced the return of his OBE received in 2009 due to the "tortured history" between Wales and the UK. Musician John Lennon returned his MBE in 1969 in response to the UK's involvement in the Nigerian Civil War and its support for the United States during the Vietnam War.

Cumming's notable film credits include *GoldenEye* and the *Spy Kids* trilogy. He won Tony Awards for producing the musical *A Strange Loop* (2022) and for his performance in *Cabaret* (1998). In 2019, he expressed pride in his role on the television series *Instinct*, which was the first US network drama to feature a gay lead character. Remembering the canceled show, he noted it was significant as it was where "millions of people will have seen a same-sex marriage portrayed for the first time."

title: "Energized and excited": Chris Hipkins becomes 41st Prime Minister of New Zealand
content:
**Tuesday, January 31, 2023**

On January 25, Chris Hipkins was sworn in as New Zealand's prime minister, succeeding Jacinda Ardern, who shocked the nation with her resignation on January 19. During the ceremony in Wellington, Governor-General Dame Cindy Kiro, representing King Charles III, appointed Hipkins as prime minister and Carmel Sepuloni as the first Pasifika New Zealander to hold the position of deputy prime minister.

Hipkins, 44, was elected unopposed to lead the Labour Party on January 22, and he is set to guide the party into the upcoming elections in October amid economic challenges and declining popularity over the past two years in the face of a stronger conservative opposition.

In his inaugural speech, Hipkins, who managed New Zealand's COVID-19 response under Ardern’s leadership, remarked: "This is the biggest privilege and responsibility of my life [...] I’m energized and excited by the challenges that lie ahead." He emphasized that addressing the cost of living would be an "absolute priority" for his new government, although he refrained from detailing specific measures so soon after taking office. Recent quarterly consumer spending figures indicated that New Zealand's inflation rate remains high at 7.2%, primarily driven by rising housing and food costs.

"New Zealanders will absolutely see in the coming weeks and months that the cost of living is at the core of our work program [...] It is our number one priority as a government, and they will witness tangible evidence of our commitment," he told reporters, while cautioning against making hasty promises.

Sepuloni expressed her appreciation for her new role and commended Hipkins’ election. On the same day, she highlighted the significance of this moment for the Pacific community, given her own heritage of Samoan, Tongan, and New Zealand European descent.

Hipkins, addressing the economic situation, promised to combat what he termed a "pandemic of inflation." He stated, "COVID-19 and the global pandemic created a health crisis. Now it has led to an economic one, and that will be the focus of my government." He also assured that economic concerns would not overshadow other crucial issues such as climate change, which he described as "one of the biggest intergenerational challenges we face."

Christopher Luxon, Leader of the Opposition, extended his congratulations to Hipkins and Sepuloni via text but criticized the Ardern government's performance as a "spectacular failure," claiming Hipkins would only provide "more of the same."

Despite previously serving as Minister of Education and Minister of Police, Hipkins is largely recognized as the 'architect' of New Zealand's COVID-19 policies. However, as noted by the Associated Press, he and his colleagues have not achieved the same level of recognition as Ardern, who emerged as a "global icon for the left."

Ardern announced her resignation after nearly fifteen years in Parliament, citing a lack of energy to continue. She is expected to remain an MP until April, allowing her to step down without triggering a by-election prior to the October elections. 

First elected to the prime ministership in a coalition government in 2017, Ardern won a landslide re-election three years later. Her tenure included navigating the nation's deadliest terrorist attack, natural disasters, and the COVID-19 pandemic.

In her final remarks as prime minister on Tuesday, Ardern expressed that the people were "the joy of the job." The following morning, staff and supporters gathered to bid her farewell as she exited the Parliament building.

William and Catherine, the Prince and Princess of Wales, publicly thanked Ardern and her family for their "friendship, leadership, and support" over the years, particularly during the time of the Queen's passing.

title: Statuette exhibition Legends of Oriental Folklore opens in Simferopol, Crimea
content:
**Wednesday, May 31, 2023**

On May 20, the exhibition "Legends of Oriental Folklore" (Russian: Легенды восточного фольклора) opened at the Museum of History of the City of Simferopol, located on Pushkin Street in the Crimean capital. Featuring over 70 statuettes representing characters from Asian folklore, the collection includes items made from bronze, brass, and stone, and coincided with the international Night of Museums.

The items were collected by Russian traveler Viktor Pinchuk during a visit to Ho Chi Minh City in 2020. In his words, "The concept of the project is to familiarize residents and guests of Crimea with the artistic creativity of the peoples of the Asia-Pacific region, indirectly contributing to the increase in geographical knowledge and interest in collecting."

title: US: Navy, UK navy respond to merchant vessel distress call in Strait of Hormuz
content:
Monday, June 5, 2023

The US Navy reported yesterday that three fast-attack craft from Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps Navy (IRGCN), with armed sailors on board, closely monitored an "internationally flagged" merchant ship in the Strait of Hormuz. In response to a distress call from the merchant ship, the USS McFaul, a guided-missile destroyer, and the Royal Navy frigate HMS Lancaster intervened, with a Lancaster-based helicopter and US P-8A Poseidon maritime patrol aircraft deployed for reconnaissance.

According to the US Navy, tensions subsided about an hour later, allowing the merchant vessel to continue its journey without further incident. 

IRGCN commander Abbas Gholamshahi denied that "extra-regional vessels [were] in the area," stating that a commercial ship flying the Marshall Islands flag had reported the presence of three civilian fast boats a few miles away, prompting the IRGCN to send vessels to address the captain's concerns.

Yesterday's incident is part of a series of maritime confrontations involving Iran since the US' unilateral withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal in 2018. The Associated Press reported, citing geolocation data, that the US had confiscated the Suez Rajan for transporting Iranian crude oil near Singapore, while Iran had seized the Advantage Sweet, a Marshall Islands-flagged tanker, in April.

title: Nationwide unrest continues for sixth night in France following fatal shooting of Nahel Merzouk
content:
**Monday, July 3, 2023** 

Unrest over the police shooting of 17-year-old Nahel Merzouk, of Algerian and Moroccan descent, during a traffic stop in Nanterre, a suburb of Paris, continued for the sixth consecutive night across France. The protests have resulted in 157 arrests last night, along with injuries and damage to schools, police stations, town halls, and businesses.

Tragically, a 24-year-old firefighter from Paris died while extinguishing a fire in a subterranean car park today.

President Emmanuel Macron convened a crisis meeting and deployed additional police forces but chose not to declare a state of emergency. He urged parents to keep their children at home and called on social media platforms to remove content related to the unrest.

Macron condemned both the shooting and the ongoing unrest, echoing the sentiments of Merzouk's grandmother. An officer involved in the incident, currently under formal investigation for voluntary homicide and in custody, claimed he aimed for Merzouk's leg but accidentally shot him in the chest.

The United Nations' human rights office has called on France to address any racism within its law enforcement practices.

title: Germany: Esslingen am Neckar hosts first Christopher Street Day
content:
**Wednesday, July 5, 2023**

On June 17, the town of Esslingen am Neckar in Baden-Württemberg, Germany, held its inaugural Christopher Street Day (CSD), celebrating LGBT pride. Wikinews reporter Ash Thawley interviewed local organizer Mo Koalick about the event.

Police estimated that between 1,200 and 1,500 people participated in the march, carrying banners with slogans like "queer struggle is class struggle" (German: queerer Kampf ist Klassenkampf). A 2017 report by the German Institute for Economic Research indicated that gay and bisexual men earn, on average, 12% less per hour (approximately €2) than their heterosexual counterparts.

In Germany and Switzerland, pride parades are referred to as CSDs, a name chosen to honor the legacy of the Stonewall riots, which took place at the Stonewall Inn on Christopher Street in New York City.

Koalick expressed a desire for increased publicity for future events and a more extensive parade route, stating, "I would have liked to decorate the town more." Nonetheless, they remarked, "Overall, I am really happy with how the first pride of Esslingen came to be a reality," adding that they were "very positively surprised."

Regarding the social climate for LGBT individuals in Germany, Koalick observed, "There are more inclusive spaces and less inclusive spaces. Baden-Württemberg is one of the more conservative areas." They noted that while "older residents are generally supportive," some "teenagers and young adults go out of their way to demonstrate their disapproval." However, Koalick acknowledged a "small improvement," highlighting that "older individuals are starting to listen," while teenagers and young adults "aren't really open to learning yet."

title: United States Coast Guard: Possible human remains in debris from imploded Titan submersible
content:
**Revised Version:**

**Wednesday, July 5, 2023**

On June 28, the United States Coast Guard announced that debris from OceanGate's Titan submersible, which is believed to have imploded during a dive to the Titanic wreck on June 18, contained "presumed human remains." Remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) from Horizon Arctic returned the debris to land earlier that same day.

The Titan lost contact with its support ship, the Polar Prince, following a descent of approximately one hour and 45 minutes. A subsequent search operation involving ships and ROVs led to the discovery of debris about 1,600 feet (488 meters) from the bow of the Titanic on June 22. Rear Admiral John Mauger of the US Coast Guard stated that the debris was "consistent with a catastrophic implosion of the vehicle."

On June 18, a United States Navy acoustic detection system identified an "anomaly consistent with an implosion or explosion" in the vicinity where the Titan was last located. An official informed NPR that the Navy opted to continue the mission "as a search and rescue and make every effort to save the lives on board." Search crews reported hearing sounds at 30-minute intervals; however, Carl Hartsfield from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute mentioned that some claimed the sounds were "banging noises." Mauger clarified that "[t]here doesn't appear to be any connection between the noises" and the missing submersible.

Due to the extreme pressure at that depth, an implosion would have instantly claimed the lives of the five individuals on board: OceanGate CEO Stockton Rush, British executive Shahzada Dawood and his 19-year-old son Suleman, British businessman Hamish Harding, and French explorer Paul-Henri Nargeolet.

title: European Space Agency's Euclid telescope launches from Florida, US
content:
**Sunday, July 2, 2023**

On Saturday, a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket successfully launched the European Space Agency's (ESA) Euclid space telescope at 11:12 AM EDT (1512 UTC) from Cape Canaveral Space Launch Complex 40 in Florida. Euclid is designed to investigate dark matter, dark energy, and the expansion of the universe.

With a budget of €1.4 billion, Euclid is expected to spend approximately one month traveling around 1,500,000 kilometers (932,057 miles) to the Lagrange point L2, situated between the Earth and the Sun, the same region as the James Webb Space Telescope. Once there, it will survey about one-third of the sky beyond the Milky Way over a six-year mission.

NASA played a key role in the development of Euclid's Near Infrared Spectrometer and Photometer. Additionally, NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope, which is currently slated for launch in May 2027, aims to provide more detailed data that could enhance the findings from Euclid. IPAC senior research scientist Yun Wang emphasized the collaborative potential of the two missions, stating, “Euclid and Roman will add up to much more than the sum of their parts. Combining their observations will give astronomers a better sense of what's actually going on in the universe.”

Originally, before the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Euclid was set to launch from French Guiana aboard a Russian Soyuz rocket in March 2023.

title: Wales: Final undecided legislators decline to run for Plaid Cymru party leader, leaving Rhun ap Iorwerth unopposed

Sioned Williams and Siân Gwenllian, the last undecided Members of the Senedd for the Plaid Cymru party, announced yesterday that neither will contest the party's leadership ahead of the June 16 deadline for the MS-only position. This paves the way for Rhun ap Iorwerth to become leader unopposed, unless another MS changes their mind.

In an interview with BBC Radio on Friday, former Plaid chairman Alun Ffred Jones commented, "A contest within a party is a good thing in almost all circumstances, but if the more experienced individuals opted not to stand for various reasons, that’s where we are. If there is to be only one candidate, it’s crucial that the party unites behind Rhun."

Former Plaid leader Leanne Wood previously advocated for the next leader to be a woman, a sentiment supported by Gwenllian and Williams. This comes after a report highlighted issues of misogyny, unwanted sexual behavior, and intimidation within the party, reportedly exacerbating under the leadership of Adam Price, who resigned in May.

Plaid Cymru, the third-largest party in the Senedd with 12 members—trailing Welsh Labour's 30 and the Welsh Conservatives' 16—supports Welsh independence from the UK. Rhun ap Iorwerth hails from Rhondda Cynon Taf and was raised in Meirionnydd and Ynys Môn. He holds a degree in politics and Welsh from Cardiff University.

title: UK sells £4 billion of government debt at highest yield since 2007
content:
**Sunday, July 9, 2023**

The United Kingdom's Debt Management Office (DMO) successfully auctioned £4 billion in government debt in the form of two-year gilt-edged securities on Wednesday, achieving an average annual yield of 5.668%, marking the highest level since June 2007.

In the UK, gilts—known as 'bonds' in other countries—are issued by the DMO as securities to finance government spending that exceeds tax revenue. Although there was strong demand, with bids exceeding £11 billion, yields reached a fifteen-year high due to traders' expectations that the Bank of England (BoE) would continue to raise interest rates amid ongoing high inflation, which has eroded returns.

On June 22, the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee raised its bank rate for the thirteenth consecutive time, increasing it from 4.5% to 5%. This decision followed "significant upside news in recent data" indicating persistent inflationary pressures. HSBC asset strategist Joseph Little commented to Reuters that the BoE might raise its main interest rate to as much as 6%, citing that "inflation pressures show greater persistency and momentum than in other Western economies, pushing the Bank into a hawkish stance." Additionally, Reuters reported that investors anticipated rates might rise to around 6.25% by December before declining.

The impact of these higher interest rates is evident, as the same gilts with a maturity date in October 2025 sold for an average yield of 4.874% last month and 3.634% in January. However, NatWest bond specialists told Reuters last week that these gilts are "one of the cheapest bonds on the UK fitted curve."

UK inflation remained steady at 8.7% in May, contrary to forecasts, while core inflation, which excludes certain items like food and energy, rose to 7.1% from 6.8% in April—the highest level since 1992. Consequently, the BoE revised its inflation projection for the end of 2023 to approximately 5%, up from an earlier estimate of 4%.

In June 2007, the UK sold £2.5 billion worth of five-year gilts with an average yield of 5.790%. 

As of 08:17 BST (0717 UTC) on Thursday, the yield on two-year gilts stood at 5.429%, while the yield on ten-year gilts was 4.548% at 08:19.

title: Heatwaves surge worldwide as researchers' analysis indicates global temperatures reaching new highs
content:
**Monday, July 10, 2023**

Last week marked a historic moment as the world experienced three of the hottest days on record, according to the Climate Reanalyzer program at the University of Maine. This trend culminated on July 6, when the average global temperature soared to a record 63 °F (17.2 °C).

The Climate Reanalyzer noted that these three days eclipsed the previous record of 62.46 °F (16.9 °C), which was tied between days in July 2022 and August 2016. Researchers attributed this alarming rise in temperature to heatwaves affecting the United States, Canada, and Europe, as well as the influence of El Niño, a climatic phenomenon characterized by elevated temperatures in the Pacific Ocean.

The data utilized by the program has been compiled by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and the University of Maine since 1979, focusing on the average global temperature at two meters above the Earth's surface. Scientists are confident that these average temperature readings represent the highest levels since systematic instrumental measurements began in the 1850s.

Furthermore, the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts declared that June 2023 was the warmest month on record. The extreme temperatures put significant strain on infrastructure and public health services, with residents across Europe and China, as well as 120 million people in the United States, facing heat advisories at various points.

Vox reported that climate change is a major driver behind this heatwave, with rising global temperatures due to greenhouse gas emissions increasing the frequency and severity of such extreme weather events. Experts warn that future heatwaves may exceed the intensity and duration of the current one.
