title: Former US President Donald Trump pleads not guilty over alleged attempts to 'subvert' 2020 presidential election results
content:
**Thursday, August 10, 2023**

Former US President Donald Trump entered a not guilty plea last Thursday in the US District Court for the District of Columbia to four felony charges related to his alleged efforts to undermine the outcome of the 2020 presidential election. These charges emerged from accusations of pursuing unlawful means to discount legitimate votes and to subvert the election results, which led to current President Joe Biden's victory and the Capitol riots on January 6, 2021.

Magistrate Judge Moxila A. Upadhyaya stated that Judge Tanya Chutkan, who is assigned to oversee the case, intends to schedule a trial during an August 28 hearing. Both prosecutors and Trump's legal team are expected to propose their preferred trial timelines by that date. However, Upadhyaya indicated that Chutkan might allow Trump to skip the hearing.

Lead prosecutor Thomas Windom asserted that proceeding swiftly with the trial would be beneficial for the case, emphasizing the importance of maintaining normal courtroom order. In contrast, defense attorney John Lauro argued for more time, stating that the weighty issues at hand required thorough analysis of the evidence provided by the prosecution. He noted, “The US has had three and a half years to investigate this matter,” requesting adequate time to prepare a fair defense.

Upadhyaya assured that there would be a fair process and trial. She also advised Trump of the conditions of his freedom, including a prohibition on discussing the case with witnesses without legal counsel present, warning that noncompliance could result in arrest.

The arraignment, lasting 27 minutes, was witnessed by three law enforcement officers who had resisted the Capitol attack, including retired Capitol Police officer Aquilino Gonell. He remarked to the Associated Press that it was the same court where many rioters had been sentenced, emphasizing the gravity of the proceedings.

Among attendees were Chief Judge James Boasberg, who presided over the grand jury's secret proceedings, as well as Judges Randy Moss and Amy Berman Jackson, the latter known for her critical sentencing of Trump supporters involved in the riots.

Lauro and Todd Blanche represented Trump’s defense team, while attorney Evan Corcoran was present in the audience. Trump's legal team has contended that Special Counsel Jack Smith violated Trump’s freedom of speech by charging him criminally.

Standing in the rain at Reagan National Airport before his flight back to New Jersey, Trump lamented it was a "very sad day for America." He claimed, "This is the persecution of the person that’s leading by very, very substantial numbers in the Republican primary and leading Biden by a lot... So if you can't beat 'em, you persecute 'em or you prosecute 'em. We can’t let this happen in America." He continues to assert his innocence.

Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, a Republican candidate for the 2024 election, was asked during a campaign stop in Iowa whether he believed the 2020 presidential election was "stolen." He replied, “I’ve said many times the election is what it is [...] All those theories did not prove to be true. But to conduct a good election that people can trust, you don’t change the rules in the middle of the game.”

Prosecutors have requested Judge Chutkan to impose a protective order to prevent Trump from disclosing sensitive evidence from discovery after he posted on his social media platform Truth Social: "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I’M COMING AFTER YOU!” Prosecutors argued this could potentially intimidate witnesses.

Trump's attorneys responded on Monday, acknowledging some documents should remain confidential but arguing against a blanket gag order, citing the constitutional right to free speech. They stated, "In a trial about First Amendment rights, the government seeks to restrict First Amendment rights."

The government countered, noting that Trump's legal team had commented on the case in the media. A hearing on this issue has been scheduled for Friday.

On Sunday, Trump expressed on Truth Social: "There is no way I can get a fair trial with the judge 'assigned' to the ridiculous freedom of speech/fair elections case [...] Everybody knows this and so does she! We will be immediately asking for recusal of this judge on very powerful grounds and likewise for a venue change, out [of] D.C." He suggested that West Virginia was "politically unbiased" compared to D.C.

On August 1, a federal grand jury indicted Trump on charges including conspiracy to defraud the United States, conspiracy to obstruct an official proceeding, and conspiracy against rights, alleging that he actively participated in efforts to contest the election results. This indictment followed a state-level indictment in New York related to falsifying business records and another federal indictment in Miami concerning the retention of classified documents.

Fulton County, Georgia, is also investigating Trump and his supporters for alleged attempts to influence the state's election results.

Unlike an impeachment, a conviction unrelated to insurrection would not have legal consequences for Trump's campaign. The indictment stated that Trump exhausted his legal remedies to contest the election results, including seeking court relief and calling for audits, while participating in a conspiracy to perpetuate his claims of victory. He referred to the election as "crooked" before traveling to D.C. for his arraignment.

The indictment alleges that Trump knowingly disseminated false claims, aware they were not supported by evidence, to generate widespread distrust and anger among the public regarding the election's legitimacy. It also details Trump's attempts to persuade state officials to change election results and his failed effort to convince then-Vice President Mike Pence to prevent the counting of electoral votes.

The grand jury also highlighted Trump's statements made during a rally on January 6, which preceded the Capitol riots, where attendees violently clashed with law enforcement. Congress reconvened later that day, with Pence overseeing the certification of the election results.

Prosecutor Jack Smith characterized the events as "an unprecedented assault on the seat of American democracy [...] fueled by lies by the defendant."

A bipartisan committee in the US House of Representatives, following an extensive investigation, recommended charging Trump with aiding an insurrection and obstructing an official proceeding. In 2021, Judge Chutkan ordered the release of Trump’s presidential records to the committee, a decision made contrary to Trump's objections, which were subsequently referenced in the August 1 indictment. Just hours before his arraignment, Trump criticized Chutkan, branding her as "unfair" on social media.

title: US Supreme Court blocks stay on federal regulation on privately made firearms
content:
**Thursday, August 10, 2023**

On Tuesday, the U.S. Supreme Court, in a 5–4 vote, temporarily reinstated a 2022 regulation on "ghost guns," or privately made firearms (PMFs). This regulation defines PMFs as firearms that are neither produced nor marked with a serial number by a "licensed manufacturer." The Court's decision stays a lower court's suspension of the regulation while the Biden administration pursues its appeal.

In a June ruling, U.S. District Judge Reed O'Connor in Fort Worth, Texas, determined that the administration lacked the authority to redefine ghost gun parts and kits as firearms. He argued that, according to Congress, a firearm cannot be considered "weapon parts or aggregations of weapon parts," regardless of their potential to be assembled into a functioning firearm.

The ATF's final rule 2021R-05F, known as the "Frame or Receiver" rule, establishes new restrictions requiring serial numbers on "easy-to-build" gun kits and further clarifies what constitutes a receiver. The rule mandates that sellers conduct background checks on buyers of kits that contain the necessary parts to construct a firearm. Previously, such kits were available without these requirements. The ATF's goal with the Frame or Receiver rule is to ensure proper marking, recordkeeping, and traceability of firearms.

John Feinblatt, president of Everytown for Gun Safety, stated, "Americans across the country will be safer thanks to the Supreme Court’s decision today to maintain ATF's life-saving ghost guns rule while the appeals process unfolds."

In response to the ruling, Cody J. Wisniewski, representing the Firearms Policy Coalition, expressed disappointment, stating, "We're deeply disappointed that the Court has paused our victory over ATF's rule, effectively redefining 'firearm' and 'frame or receiver' under federal law."

The Gun Control Act of 1968 did not address privately-made firearms intended for "personal, lawful" use, making their creation legal as long as the individual could legally own a firearm. For certain regulated items, such as machine guns under the National Firearms Act, the ATF is responsible for approval and registration, mirroring the process for purchasing from a Federal Firearms License (FFL) holder.

According to the ATF, advancements in technology and the widespread availability of manufacturing instructions have led to a rise in privately-made firearms. The ATF has reported an increase in unserialized firearms found during criminal investigations, which prompted the creation of the "Frame or Receiver" rule.

title: US: Writers, entertainment producers' groups meet two months into writers' strike; writers' says 'no agreement'
content:
**Wednesday, August 9, 2023**

Officials from the Writers Guild of America (WGA) and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers (AMPTP) met for the first time on Friday in California since the writers' strike began on May 2. The meeting focused on establishing a framework for negotiations, with participants providing a preview of the issues each side plans to address when talks resume. WGA representatives informed union members that there was “no agreement” reached, noting that the AMPTP needed to consult with its member studios.

The AMPTP did not comment on the meeting to IndieWire. The WGA stated that the AMPTP intended to suggest replicating the agreement made with the Directors Guild of America in June for issues common to both groups, a proposal that the WGA has dismissed.

In a memo, the WGA reported that Lombardini, the AMPTP's representative, indicated a willingness to enhance offers on certain writer-specific minimums for television and engage in discussions about artificial intelligence. However, she did not agree to address concerns regarding the preservation of the writers' room or success-based residuals.

The AMPTP characterized the WGA's proposals related to the writers' room as a "hiring quota." The WGA memo further noted that Lombardini did not express any willingness to consider issues affecting screenwriters or other proposals still under review.

The WGA indicated that if an agreement is reached with the AMPTP, it plans to maintain the strike until the SAG-AFTRA actors' union resolves its own disputes. After the meeting, the WGA reported that the AMPTP requested a media blackout, although information was leaked to industry publications.

During the meeting, AMPTP President Carol Lombardini initially resisted the idea of media coverage; however, studio executives, including Sony Pictures CEO Tony Vinciquerra, urged her to proceed with the discussions, according to a report in Puck.

title: Federal grand jury indicts former US President Donald Trump in classified documents inquiry
content:
**Revised Version:**

On Thursday, June 8, 2023, a federal grand jury in Miami, Florida, indicted former US President Donald Trump on 37 counts, including willfully retaining national defense secrets, conspiracy to obstruct justice, concealing documents in a federal investigation, and making false statements. This marks the first federal indictment of a former US president. 

Trump's attorney, Jim Trusty, announced that Trump plans to attend a court hearing scheduled for Tuesday following a summons. According to the indictment, Trump and his aides transported hundreds of classified documents from the White House to his Mar-a-Lago residence in Palm Beach, Florida, as his presidency concluded in January 2021. The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) began seeking these documents in May 2021. By January 2022, Trump’s staff turned over 197 documents, labeled ranging from "CONFIDENTIAL" to "TOP SECRET," which led NARA to request an investigation from the US Department of Justice (DoJ) the following month.

The indictment reveals that staff member Walt Nauta, Trump's co-defendant, discovered documents in December 2021, one of which was marked "SECRET//REL TO USA, FVEY," indicating it should only be shared with the US and other members of the Five Eyes alliance. Trump also reportedly stored classified documents at his Bedminster, New Jersey club. The indictment includes a partial transcript of a conversation where Trump informed an interviewer, a publisher, and two aides that he was sharing secret information with them that he had not declassified prior to leaving office, contradicting his earlier claims about all documents held at Mar-a-Lago.

Additionally, the indictment alleges that a Trump attorney made false statements to the FBI and DoJ last June, asserting that she and her colleague were providing all classified documents when, according to the indictment, Trump had directed Nauta to move documents out of the room while the second attorney conducted a search for compliance with a May 2022 grand jury subpoena. In August, the FBI, equipped with a warrant and security camera footage that appeared to show Nauta moving documents, executed a search at Mar-a-Lago and seized 102 documents labeled classified.

Special Counsel Jack Smith filed the charges in the Southern District of Florida District Court. He was appointed by US Attorney General Merrick Garland to investigate both the January 6 US Capitol attack and Trump's handling of classified documents.

title: Tens of thousands march in 25th Tel Aviv Pride parade
content:
**Revised Version:**

On Thursday, June 8, 2023, approximately 150,000 people paraded in Tel Aviv, Israel, as part of the 25th annual edition of the Middle East's largest LGBT pride festival, according to The Times of Israel. 

The Associated Press (AP) reported a festive atmosphere, contrasting it with the June 1 pride parade in Jerusalem, where over 2,000 police officers were deployed for security. Many attendees joined the Tel Aviv celebration in significant numbers.

Ohad Huri, an Israeli who dyed his beard in rainbow colors, shared his thoughts with the AP: "I'm a minority. I want to save my rights. I want to fight for the rights of other minorities. I want equality. That's about it."

Omer Elad, head of a local transgender group, told The Times of Israel that the parade held particular significance given Israel's current political climate. title: Italy: Former PM Silvio Berlusconi dies at age 86
content:
**Tuesday, June 13, 2023**

Silvio Berlusconi, the former Prime Minister of Italy, passed away yesterday at the San Raffaele Hospital in Milan at the age of 86. 

Berlusconi's health had been deteriorating; his doctor reported in April that he had been battling leukaemia "for some time" after being admitted to intensive care for a lung infection.

He was the longest-serving prime minister of Italy since World War II, holding office across three non-consecutive terms between 1994 and 2011. Berlusconi's party, Forza Italia, has been a part of Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's Brothers of Italy-led government since October.

His career was marked by numerous controversies, including allegations of organizing "bunga bunga" sex parties at his villas, which reportedly involved female minors. While acquitted of those charges and related accusations of bribing a witness, he was convicted of tax fraud, engaging in sex with a minor prostitute, and abuse of power for attempting to have police release the detainee after she was arrested for alleged theft.

A spokesperson for British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak remarked, "Silvio Berlusconi made a significant impact on Italian politics over several decades, and our thoughts are with the Italian people and his family."

A national day of mourning was set for Wednesday.

title: England: Parts of Birmingham area flood; music festival evacuates
content:
**Tuesday, July 11, 2023**

Heavy downpours on Saturday led to flooding in parts of Birmingham, England, prompting a yellow weather warning from the Met Office. The Mostly Jazz Funk and Soul Festival in Moseley was evacuated, with organizers describing the weather as "biblical." 

They expressed their gratitude, stating, "Thank you to everyone for your patience and cooperation. We're relieved that everyone made it out safely and appreciate all our staff for managing a safe evacuation."

Severn Trent postponed their Big Boost for Brum job fair, which was expected to attract 1,000 attendees, after the event venue at Birmingham City F.C.'s St Andrew's stadium experienced flooding.

Local Instagram account imjustbrum shared a Reel showcasing flooding on streets in Alum Rock and other areas of the city, as well as water leaking from the roof of a PureGym and two shopping center locations. The post humorously noted, "Birmingham really does have more canals than Venice!"

Residents in Erdington reported that floodwaters entered homes, but local resident Bradshaw told Birmingham Live that the "treacherous conditions" had not deterred "the plague of boy racers speeding down Spring Lane."

Major roads in Stechford and Selly Park were also affected, including Alum Rock Road and Highgate Road, while slip roads from the M6 onto the A38M were closed due to flooding, according to National Highways.

The Met Office's Sunday forecast predicted rain between 15:00 and 19:00, with a resumption at 20:00: "A fine start with some sunny spells, though hazy at times. Scattered showers are expected in the afternoon, potentially turning heavy and thundery. It will feel less muggy, though still warm during sunny spells, with a maximum temperature of 24°C (75°F)."

The Mostly Jazz Funk and Soul Festival was evacuated again on Sunday, with a tweet stating, "This is a safety announcement. We have been tracking a storm, and with lightning strikes nearby, it’s not safe to remain in the park, even under marquees. You must evacuate now using the nearest exit. We recommend seeking shelter in the cafes and pubs of Moseley Village until the storm passes. Once it's safe, you're welcome to come and go as you please for the rest of the day. Please check our socials for updates. Stay safe, MJFS."

title: Twitter threatens to sue Meta over rival app Threads
content:
**Tuesday, July 11, 2023**

On Wednesday, Alex Spiro, an attorney representing Twitter, sent a letter to Meta Platforms CEO Mark Zuckerberg, accusing the company of stealing trade secrets to develop its "copycat" app, Threads. The letter alleged that Meta engaged in "systemic, willful, and unlawful misappropriation" of Twitter's trade secrets and other intellectual property by hiring "dozens" of employees who had access to sensitive information from Twitter. It called for Meta to "immediately cease using any Twitter trade secrets or highly confidential information."

In response to the letter, Elon Musk, who acquired Twitter for $44 billion last year, tweeted that "competition is fine, cheating is not."

The Threads app features an interface similar to Twitter's, enabling users to post messages of up to 500 characters and interact through replies, reposts, and quotes. In a post on the platform, Zuckerberg expressed optimism about Threads' potential, stating, "It'll take some time, but I believe there should be a public conversation app with over a billion users. Twitter has had the opportunity to do this but hasn't nailed it. Hopefully, we will."

Within just two days of its launch in more than 100 countries, Threads garnered over 70 million sign-ups, according to Instagram head Adam Mosseri. However, the app has not yet launched in the European Union due to Meta's concerns about compliance with the restrictions imposed by the Digital Markets Act passed last year.

title: US: Tulsa residents approve $814 million infrastructure package
content:
**Sunday, August 13, 2023**

On Tuesday, voters in Tulsa, Oklahoma, approved an $814 million infrastructure improvement package known as "Improve Our Tulsa 3." The measure garnered more than the required 60% of ballots cast.

Tulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum campaigned for its approval, stating, "We have allowed facilities across the city to fall behind in maintenance. Earlier this year, my colleagues on the council and I toured several critical city facilities. What we saw— and I say this as someone who loves Tulsa—was embarrassing."

However, Tulsa City Councilor Grant Miller raised concerns about the measure, arguing that the council had not been given adequate time to review the proposed projects.

The measure will maintain the city’s sales tax at its current rate of 3.65%, while allocating some revenue towards the proposed improvements through the issuance of $42 million in additional bonds, along with existing bonds.

Funding from the measure will include $95 million for housing projects, $93.8 million for previously approved street projects, $46 million for street widening initiatives, $58.5 million for enhancements to the fire department's vehicles, $47.5 million for a facility to house police and municipal courts, and $79.7 million for upgrades to Tulsa's Performing Arts Center.

title: U.S. tennis player Coco Gauff wins U.S. Open women's singles tournament
content:
**Monday, September 11, 2023**

U.S. tennis player Coco Gauff triumphed over Belarusian Aryna Sabalenka in the women's singles final of the U.S. Open on Saturday at Arthur Ashe Stadium in New York City. Gauff clinched the victory in a thrilling three-set match, finishing with scores of 2–6, 6–3, and 6–2, securing her first Grand Slam title.

In her post-match comments, a stunned Gauff expressed, "I feel like I'm a little bit in shock in this moment," adding, "I'm just thankful for this moment; I don't have any words for it, to be honest."

At just 19 years old, Gauff is the first American teenager to win the U.S. Open women's title since Serena Williams, who was also 19 years old when she faced her sister Venus Williams in the final in 2001. Gauff is the first American to capture the title since Serena Williams did in 1999.

Earlier in the tournament, Gauff defeated Latvia's Jeļena Ostapenko in the quarterfinals with a commanding score of 6–0, 6–2, setting up her semifinal match against Czech player Karolína Muchová, which she also won in straight sets on Thursday to advance to the final.

Sabalenka, 25, a semifinalist in both 2021 and 2022 at the U.S. Open, claimed her first Grand Slam title earlier this year at the Australian Open.

Reflecting on her performance, Sabalenka stated, "I'm most proud that I was able to handle my emotions pretty well and focus on myself, not on the ranking." She acknowledged her struggles during the match, saying, "Today on the court, I was overthinking and missing balls I shouldn't be missing."

title: England: West Midlands region floods amid heavy rain, high winds

title: Wikinews interviews Tom Pashby, leader of campaign group Include Mx

Wikinews reporter Ash Thawley interviewed Tom Pashby, head of the advocacy group Include Mx, on June 10. title: U.S. federal judge upholds Oregon Ballot Measure 114 gun permit requirement, magazine regulations
content:
**Thursday, July 20, 2023**

On Friday, U.S. District Court Judge Karin Immergut upheld the constitutionality of Oregon Ballot Measure 114 in response to four consolidated lawsuits. The measure prohibits the possession, use, production, and transfer of large capacity magazines (LCMs) capable of holding more than ten rounds of ammunition, with certain exceptions, and mandates that prospective gun owners obtain a permit.

The plaintiffs included special interest groups, gun sellers and owners, county sheriffs, and security professionals. Immergut's ruling did not overturn Harney County Circuit Court Judge Robert Raschio's December 6 order, which temporarily halted Measure 114's implementation; a trial related to that order is set for September.

Immergut affirmed that the "permit-to-purchase framework," which includes background checks, safety training, and mental health evaluations, aligns with regulations deemed constitutional by the United States Supreme Court under the Second Amendment. She also stated that regulating LCMs is consistent with the nation’s historical approach to managing particularly dangerous firearms to safeguard public safety.

The judge highlighted comments from Mark Hanish, former Vice President of Marketing and Sales at manufacturer Surefire, who testified that the same LCMs are sold to both the U.S. Department of Defense and civilians. Immergut concluded that LCMs, “even in civilian hands,” are closely associated with military weaponry.

During the seven-day trial, attorneys for the plaintiffs contended that magazines are essential for the operation of firearms and, as such, should be protected under the Second Amendment. Immergut countered that “while magazines may often be necessary to render a firearm operable, LCMs are not.”

Oregon Attorney General Ellen Rosenblum praised Immergut's ruling, stating, “Our team looks forward to ultimately prevailing in the state courts [...] Measure 114's provisions – passed by Oregon voters – are common sense safety measures that will save lives." 

In contrast, the Oregon Firearms Federation criticized the ruling as "simple nonsense" and expressed confidence that it would be overturned by the 9th Circuit.

Measure 114 was approved by 50.65% of Oregon voters on November 8, 2022.

title: Mark Rutte Dutch caretaker cabinet announces election in November
content:
Sunday, July 16, 2023

The Netherlands is set to hold elections on November 22 following a recommendation from Interior Minister Hanke Bruins Slot, announced by Prime Minister Mark Rutte's caretaker government on Friday. This decision comes just a week after Rutte's government resigned due to disagreements over asylum policies.

As of July 1, the Farmer-Citizen Movement (BoerBurgerBeweging), led by Caroline van der Plas, was leading the Politico polling for the upcoming election.

Rutte, who has served four consecutive terms as Prime Minister and leads the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (Volkspartij voor Vrijheid en Democratie), submitted his resignation to King Willem-Alexander on July 8. He later announced his decision to retire from politics entirely, stating it was a personal choice and not a result of the government's collapse.

The VVD, with the support of the Christian Democratic Appeal (Christen-Democratisch Appèl, CDA), introduced proposals to limit the influx of refugee children into the Netherlands and to keep refugee families separated for at least two years, prompting opposition from the Christian Union (ChristenUnie) and Democrats 66 (Democraten 66).

In February, the CDA suggested implementing a system to distinguish between temporary asylum seekers, who would be granted asylum for one to three years (extendable if their country remained in conflict), and permanent refugees.

Asylum applications in the Netherlands rose by a third in 2022, exceeding 46,000.

title: Georgia grand jury indicts former US President Trump, alleging 'conspiracy to unlawfully change outcome' of 2020 presidential election
content:
**Sunday, August 20, 2023**

On Monday, a Fulton County, Georgia grand jury in Atlanta indicted nineteen individuals, including former President Donald Trump, on a total of 41 counts, with Trump himself facing thirteen charges. The grand jury alleged that they "refused to accept that Trump lost" the 2020 election, both in Georgia and nationally, and knowingly participated in a conspiracy to unlawfully alter the election outcome in Trump's favor.

The indictment stated that the conspiracy aimed to commit two or more acts of racketeering activity in Fulton County, elsewhere in Georgia, and in other states. Following the indictments, Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis informed the press that the accused had eleven days to surrender.

Trump was charged under the Georgia Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO), along with his co-defendants. His charges included three counts of soliciting a public officer to violate their oath, conspiracy to impersonate a public officer, two counts each of conspiracy to commit forgery in the first degree and false statements and writings, conspiracy to file false documents, and filing false documents. 

On the day of the indictment, Trump asserted, "I didn't tamper with the election!" His 2024 presidential campaign characterized the prosecution led by Willis as "election interference," claiming the "timing of this latest coordinated strike" by a biased prosecutor in a predominantly Democratic jurisdiction undermined public trust. Trump has previously called for Willis's disqualification based on her public comments regarding the case.

On Tuesday, Trump announced via his social media platform, Truth Social, that a "Large, Complex, Detailed but Irrefutable REPORT on the Presidential Election Fraud which took place in Georgia" was nearly ready and would be presented at a major news conference on Monday at 11:00 A.M. in Bedminster, New Jersey. However, on Thursday, he retracted that announcement, stating that his lawyers preferred to submit what he called "Irrefutable & Overwhelming evidence of Election Fraud & Irregularities" through formal legal filings as they sought to dismiss the indictment.

This fourth case follows prior indictments of Trump on charges of falsification of business records in New York City, purposeful retention of classified documents in Miami, and efforts to subvert the 2020 election results in Washington, D.C. Unlike impeachment and conviction by Congress, a criminal conviction unrelated to insurrection would not affect Trump's presidential campaign; however, as the charges are at the state level, he cannot issue pardons or dismiss state prosecutors.

The 98-page indictment named an additional 30 individuals involved in the conspiracy, though they were not charged. It details Trump's attempts to persuade state officials, including Governor Brian Kemp and Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, to alter election results—most notably during a phone call on January 2, 2021, during which he asked Raffensperger to "find" votes to overturn Biden's victory.

The indictment alleges Trump made false claims of election fraud and enlisted individuals to act as false electors, with state Republican Party chairman David Shafer and Cathleen Latham among those charged. Some participants were reportedly informed by the Trump campaign that they would only cast their electoral votes if legal attempts to contest Biden's win succeeded. The grand jury also indicted Shafer and Mike Roman, another participant in the scheme.

Furthermore, Trump’s attorneys allegedly made multiple attempts to persuade the Republican-majority Georgia legislature to address their election fraud claims. The indictment also mentioned Jeffrey Clark, a top official at the U.S. Department of Justice, who prepared a never-sent letter urging the Georgia legislature to convene a special session regarding the election results.

Additionally, the grand jury accused several defendants of falsely alleging election crimes against Fulton County election worker Ruby Freeman, using these claims as a basis to pressure Georgia's legislature to change the election outcome.

Mark Meadows, Trump’s former Chief of Staff, is also facing charges. The grand jury accused him of trying to gain unauthorized access to a Cobb County civic center where audits of election-related signatures were taking place in December 2020. He was indicted for violating RICO and soliciting a public officer to violate their oath, linked to the scheduling of Trump's call with Raffensperger.

The indictment also charged Latham with participating in efforts to compromise ballots and election machinery in Coffee County, Georgia. In Georgia, prosecutors can convene special grand juries for investigations, and Willis did so about a year into her probe in 2022. Testimony before the special grand jury included individuals like Eastman, Giuliani, Meadows, and Ken Chesebro, who were subsequently charged by the regular grand jury. Others who testified included former national security advisor Mike Flynn and Republican legislators Senator Lindsey Graham and Representative Jody Hice.

Both Willis and Judge Robert McBurney, who oversaw the special grand jury's proceedings, indicated that Shafer was at the highest risk of prosecution among the pro-Trump electors.

title: Estonian parliament passes legalization of same-sex marriage
content:
**Thursday, June 22, 2023**

On Tuesday, Estonia's parliament approved an amendment to its Family Law Act with a vote of 55–34, allowing same-sex marriages to commence on January 1, 2024. If signed into law by the president, Estonia will become the first former Soviet country to legalize same-sex marriage.

Previously, the 2014 Registered Partnership Act, which took effect in 2016, provided civil unions for same-sex couples. However, these unions did not offer the same legal protections and adoption rights as marriage, restricting adoption to instances where one partner was already a registered parent.

Prime Minister Kaja Kallas expressed her pride in the decision, stating, "We're building a society where everyone's rights are respected and people can love freely." She emphasized that marriage is a fundamental right for everyone, adding, "This decision brings Estonia in line with other Nordic countries and democratic nations worldwide that have embraced marriage equality. It does not take away from anyone but rather gives something significant to many, showcasing our society's caring and respectful nature."

A 2012 poll by the Estonian Human Rights Centre indicated that only 34% of the population supported same-sex marriage. By April of this year, that figure had risen to 53%.

title: Wikinews attends US debut of film The People's Joker
content:
**Tuesday, July 25, 2023**

On July 15, Wikinews attended the U.S. general debut and second overall showing of *The People's Joker*—an unauthorized film adaptation of the iconic comic book villain, described by Decider as a coming-of-age comedy—at the Roy and Edna Disney/CalArts Theater in Los Angeles as part of the LGBT film festival Outfest. Filmmakers Vera Drew and Bri LeRose were in attendance.

This marks director Drew's first feature film, although she has previously worked in various roles on television productions. Drew characterized *The People's Joker* as "autobiographical," with the main character, whom she plays, aiming to break into comedy while navigating gender dysphoria. Like Drew, this character undergoes a gender transition, adopting the persona of Joker the Harlequin, an anti-humor comic and villain.

Cowriters Drew and LeRose participated in a Q&A session with moderator and audience members. Both expressed their former admiration for *Saturday Night Live*, but they also voiced critiques, with Drew labeling it "part of the military–industrial complex." Regarding actor and puppeteer David Liebe Hart, Drew referred to him as a "Yoda" who provided valuable advice during production.

The rest of the cast opted not to appear on stage in solidarity with an ongoing actors' strike.

In the days leading up to its debut at the 2022 Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF), Drew made final edits to *The People's Joker* just before boarding a flight. Following that premiere, she received a letter from Warner Bros. While the letter did not issue cease and desist demands, it warned that "copyright law prohibits appropriating the Batman character and universe" for her autobiographical narrative. The film has since had several private screenings.

Drew mentioned that her team is currently planning a distribution strategy for *The People's Joker*.

During the COVID-19 pandemic, LeRose commissioned Drew for $12 to re-edit Todd Phillips' film *Joker* into a comedic version. This collaboration eventually evolved into a script that fictionalizes Drew's life, culminating in *The People's Joker*.

Outfest took place from July 13 to Sunday.

title: Russian government: Mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin recorded on plane that crashed without survivors
content:
**Friday, August 25, 2023**

Yevgeny Prigozhin, the 62-year-old Russian businessman and leader of the Wagner Group private military company, was among the ten passengers on board an Embraer plane that crashed in Tver Oblast on Wednesday, leaving no survivors, according to the Russian Federal Air Transport Agency. His company had recently engaged in a brief mutiny against government forces in June, advancing towards Moscow.

A Telegram account known as The Grey Zone, which supports Wagner, claimed without evidence that the jet was "shot down by an anti-aircraft system operated by the Russian Ministry of Defence." They noted, "Today marks exactly two months since the march of justice."

The plane, an Embraer Legacy 600 with the tail number RA-02795, was sanctioned by the United States in 2019 due to its connections to Prigozhin. Flight data revealed that approximately thirty minutes into the flight from Moscow to Saint Petersburg, the aircraft began descending rapidly at nearly 8,000 feet per minute before ceasing altitude transmission around 6:19 PM (15:19 UTC) after fluctuating between gaining and losing altitude from a cruising height of approximately 28,000 feet.

The Federal Air Transport Agency confirmed that an investigation has begun, identifying other passengers on board as Sergey Propustin, Evgeniy Makaryan, Aleksandr Totmin, Valeriy Chekalov, Dmitry Utkin—who served as a Wagner field commander and was linked to military intelligence, Nikolay Matuseev, and crew members Commander Aleksei Levshin, co-pilot Rustam Karimov, and flight attendant Kristina Raspopova.

Russian government spokesperson Dmitry Peskov denied any involvement in the crash, stating, "There has been a lot of speculation surrounding this incident and the tragic deaths of those on board, including Yevgeny Prigozhin. Naturally, the West presents this speculation with a specific bias. This is all sheer lies... It is best to rely on facts, but currently, those facts are still being gathered through the ongoing investigation."

During a televised address yesterday, President Vladimir Putin expressed "sincere condolences to the families of all the victims," referring to Prigozhin as a "talented businessman" whom he had known since the early 1990s. He added, "He was a man with a complicated fate, who made significant mistakes in life... He achieved results that were necessary both for himself and for our collective cause in recent months."

According to a U.S. official who spoke with ABC News, the prevailing theory is that an explosion, possibly from a bomb, caused the crash. This assessment was reinforced by Brigadier General Patrick Ryder, who indicated that while intelligence suggested Prigozhin was "likely killed" in the crash, there was no current evidence of a surface-to-air missile being involved. Earlier reports from U.S. government sources also mentioned an explosion as a potential cause.

While vacationing in Lake Tahoe, U.S. President Joe Biden commented to the press that he did not "know for a fact what happened but I'm not surprised." He added, "Not much happens in Russia without Putin's involvement, but I don't know enough to know the answer."

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy's advisor, Mykhailo Podolyak, suggested that the "demonstrative elimination of Prigozhin and the Wagner command two months after the coup attempt is a signal from Putin to Russia's elites ahead of the 2024 elections."

Known as "Putin's chef," Prigozhin was born in 1961 in Saint Petersburg, then Leningrad. He began his criminal history with a twelve-year prison sentence for robbery and fraud in 1981, from which he was released in 1990.

Samantha de Bendern of the Royal Institute of International Affairs remarked in a Sky News interview that Prigozhin quickly transitioned from working in a flea market hot dog business to becoming a key figure in the new post-Soviet Russian elite through food contracts awarded by the government.

In 2018, the U.S. indicted Prigozhin over alleged financial support for the Internet Research Agency, which the Department of Justice accused of attempting to interfere with U.S. political processes, including the 2016 presidential election.

Prigozhin claimed to have established Wagner in 2014, which fought alongside pro-Russian rebels in the War in Donbas and also operated in various African nations, including Mali, Mozambique, and Sudan. U.S. estimates suggested that by late March 2022, Wagner fielded 1,000 fighters in Ukraine, which grew to 50,000 by December, with many of these fighters being recruited from prisons.

In November, Prigozhin infamously stated that "[a] dog receives a dog's death" in reference to the brutal killing of a Wagner deserter. The Institute for the Study of War has accused Wagner of committing war crimes.

As Wagner troops engaged in intense battles for Bakhmut, Prigozhin publicly demanded ammunition from Russian military leaders, including Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and Chief of General Staff Valery Gerasimov. After capturing the city and receiving praise from Putin, he criticized the military for failing to provide adequate support and threatened to withdraw his forces.

On June 23, Prigozhin called for the resignation of military leadership and ordered his forces to advance on Moscow, resulting in clashes that reportedly left around fifteen government soldiers dead. However, he later chose to turn back and seek a peaceful resolution. A deal brokered by Belarus allowed Prigozhin and Wagner forces to avoid legal consequences for their rebellion.

On July 3, Prigozhin stated on social media that his intentions had been to combat treachery and mobilize society, asserting that significant progress was made and promising further victories at the front. His first video since the rebellion surfaced on Monday.

title: US: Russian fighter jet's flare damaged drone over Syria
content:
**Wednesday, July 26, 2023**

US Air Forces Central reported that a Russian Sukhoi Su-35 fighter jet flew dangerously close to a US MQ-9 drone conducting an anti-ISIS mission over Syria on Sunday. The statement indicated that the Russian pilot released flares, one of which damaged the MQ-9's propeller, although the drone returned safely to its base.

Lieutenant General Alex Grynkewich, commander of US Air Forces Central, commented, "The Russian fighter's blatant disregard for flight safety detracts from our mission to ensure the enduring defeat of ISIS." Both nations maintain a military presence in Syria, with Russia backing President Bashar al-Assad's regime and the US conducting Operation Inherent Resolve against ISIS with about 900 troops. The Syrian and Russian governments have expressed opposition to the US presence in Syria. title: France: Quimper, Finistère hosts second pride festival

Quimper, a city in Finistère, France, celebrated the second edition of its annual pride festival, "Pride of Quimper" (French: Pride de Quimper), on June 17. The festivities commenced at Place Saint-Corentin in the city center.

title: UK Conservative Party loses two seats in by-elections, retains former PM Johnson's
content:
**Revised Version:**

**Sunday, July 30, 2023**

In the by-elections held on July 20, the UK Conservative Party lost control of Somerton and Frome, as well as Selby and Ainsty, while managing to retain their seat in Uxbridge and South Ruislip. These shifts followed the resignations of Members of Parliament (MPs) David Warburton, Nigel Adams, and former Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

The Conservative Party had previously held all three seats in the past three elections: 2015, 2017, and 2019. The Liberal Democrats' Sarah Dyke won in Somerton and Frome, capturing approximately 55% of the vote. Following her victory, she stated that the Conservatives had "let down and taken [voters] for granted for far too long."

David Warburton resigned from his position in June after being suspended by the Conservative parliamentary group in April of the previous year due to an inquiry involving admitted cocaine use and allegations of sexual harassment. Labour secured victory in Selby and Ainsty with a 46% vote share, sending Keir Mather to the House of Commons as the youngest member at just 25 years old. Mather remarked that the party had "rewritten the rules on where Labour can win."

Former MP Nigel Adams stepped down last month, citing a desire to pursue opportunities in the private sector, particularly after he did not receive a resignation honor from Boris Johnson. In Uxbridge and South Ruislip, Conservative Steve Tuckwell won with 45% of the vote share and a majority of 495 votes, attributing the Conservatives' victory to opposition against Mayor of London Sadiq Khan's proposed Ultra Low Emission Zone expansion.

Boris Johnson resigned from Parliament immediately before a committee published the Partygate report, which examined the accuracy of his testimony regarding alleged lockdown breaches. He criticized the report as "riddled with inaccuracies and reeks of prejudice," claiming he had no formal means to contest its findings.

Prior to the election results, Amanda Milling, the MP for Cannock Chase, declined to comment on the by-elections. Since December 2021, the Conservative Party has consistently lagged behind the Labour Party in Politico's Poll of Polls. In October, Labour's support reached a peak of 52% following Liz Truss's ascension to the premiership. As of July 24, Labour was polling at 46%, while the Conservatives stood at 26%.

title: NASA's OSIRIS-REx arrives in Houston, US after returning asteroid samples to Earth
content:
**Tuesday, September 26, 2023**

On Monday, a capsule from NASA's Origins, Spectral Interpretation, Resource Identification and Security – Regolith Explorer (OSIRIS-REx) spacecraft, containing samples from the asteroid Bennu, arrived in Houston, Texas. The capsule was headed to the Johnson Space Center (JSC) after successfully landing in the Utah Test and Training Range the previous day. This marked NASA's first return of asteroid samples.

As of Sunday, the capsule was in a cleanroom where the sample container was undergoing a nitrogen purge to preserve the samples' purity by preventing contamination from Earth's atmosphere. Staff plan to disassemble the container, catalog its contents, and eventually distribute samples to researchers at other institutions.

NASA Administrator Bill Nelson praised the OSIRIS-REx team for their "picture-perfect mission — the first American asteroid sample return in history," emphasizing that the findings will enhance our understanding of the solar system's origins and formations. He also noted that the samples could provide insights into asteroids that may pose a threat to Earth.

OSIRIS-REx launched in September 2016 and reached Bennu in December 2018. For nearly two years, NASA scientists meticulously selected the optimal site for sample collection. In October 2020, the spacecraft used a robotic arm to touch the asteroid's surface and inject nitrogen gas to collect material. Approximately 8.8 ounces of debris was secured in its receptacle out of around six metric tons of material. The spacecraft initiated its return journey to Earth in May 2021.

The sample capsule was released from an altitude of 63,000 miles as OSIRIS-REx passed by Earth. It entered the atmosphere at 10:42 EDT (1442 UTC) and landed about ten minutes later. Recovery teams utilized radar and other instruments to track the capsule, ensuring its secure transport to JSC.

Since its launch, OSIRIS-REx has traversed 3.86 billion miles. With the sample-return phase now complete, the spacecraft will continue its mission towards the asteroid Apophis. To reflect its new purpose, the mission has been renamed to Origins, Spectral Interpretation, Resource Identification, Security-APophis EXplorer (OSIRIS-APEX).

title: US government sues SpaceX, claims hiring discrimination against asylees
content:
**Tuesday, August 29, 2023** 

On Thursday, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a civil complaint in an intra-departmental court against SpaceX, alleging hiring discrimination against asylees. The Department aims for "fair consideration and back pay" for those affected by the alleged discrimination, along with other damages as determined by the court and a commitment from SpaceX to change its hiring practices to prevent future discrimination.

The government contends that the company, founded and owned by Elon Musk, misrepresented its hiring capabilities, claiming it could only employ U.S. citizens or permanent residents due to export regulations. This stance reportedly discouraged asylees from applying for jobs.

Additionally, the government asserts that SpaceX did not adequately consider applications for various positions, including those requiring advanced degrees, as well as roles for welders and cooks.

title: West Midlands, UK Metro stops open at Pipers Row, Wolverhampton Railway Station
content:
**Friday, September 29, 2023**

On September 17, two new tram stops were inaugurated in the West Midlands Metro system in Wolverhampton city centre: Pipers Row and Wolverhampton Railway Station. Wikinews reporter Ash Thawley interviewed David Rock, a University of Birmingham student residing in Selly Oak, after he rode the extension from approximately 16:30 to 17:30 on the same day.

This new segment, located in the Metro's Zone 4, branches off from an existing line after The Royal. The terminus for that line, Wolverhampton St George's, will remain operational, with "every other Metro [terminating there] as part of a 'shopper's service'," according to the Midland Metro Alliance. The alliance cited the "convenient location close to Wolverhampton's shopping district" as a reason for keeping this stop open. It is expected to close "later this autumn" for maintenance work, as stated in a press release from the West Midlands Metro.

The extension faced delays and was initially scheduled for completion in 2019. The Metro has now shifted its focus to future service expansions, including the extension to Brierley Hill.

title: Belgian broadcaster reveal nation's Eurovision 2024 entrant
content:
**Belgium Selects Mustii as First Entrant for Eurovision 2024**

Belgium has become the first country to announce its entrant for the 2024 Eurovision Song Contest, with public broadcaster RTBF revealing that Thomas "Mustii" Mustin will represent the nation. Mustii, a singer and actor, is set to join the judging panel of Drag Race Belgique next year. He has released several singles and two studio albums, titled *21st Century Boy* and *It's Happening Now*.

In an Instagram Reel on the @eurovision page, Mustii expressed his excitement: "Hi, this is Mustii. I'm super happy and super proud to be representing Belgium in Sweden next year at the Eurovision Song Contest. It's going to be amazing. It's going to be unbelievable. See you guys!"

Reflecting on his selection, Mustii told RTBF, "it's a challenge that I want to take on." When asked about his desired ranking, he stated, "[m]y goal is to make an impression no matter what. Above all, I want the performance to be fair, sincere, and authentic. I also want to feel comfortable in my skin and proud of my performance. That's the primary objective."

The Eurovision 2024 festival is scheduled to take place in Malmö on May 7, 9, and 11, following this year's victory by Swedish artist Loreen.

title: Former U.S. First Lady Rosalynn Carter dies at 96
content:
**Sunday, November 26, 2023**

The Carter Center announced on the afternoon of November 19 (1910 UTC) that Rosalynn Carter, the former First Lady of the United States and wife of former President Jimmy Carter, has passed away at the age of 96. According to the Center, she "died peacefully, with family by her side" at her home in Plains, Georgia.

Two days prior to her death, Rosalynn Carter was receiving palliative care at her residence following a diagnosis of dementia earlier in May. In a statement, former President Carter remembered her as his "equal partner in everything I ever accomplished." He expressed that "as long as Rosalynn was in the world, I always knew somebody loved and supported me." The couple were married for 77 years and had four children together.

Born Eleanor Rosalynn Smith in 1927, Rosalynn was the youngest of four siblings. Her father passed away when she was just 13, and her mother supported the family as a seamstress. She helped work on her husband’s family's peanut farm during their years together.

Often dubbed the "Steel Magnolia" by reporters, Rosalynn became a prominent advocate for mental health after her husband’s presidency ended in 1981. In recognition of her contributions, she was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom by Bill Clinton in 1999, one of the highest civilian honors in the United States.

Former President Jimmy Carter, who is the oldest living former U.S. president, announced several months ago that he wished to forgo further medical treatment.

title: Russian photographer Viktor Pinchuk presents exhibition The Architectural Art of the Vanished Civilizations of Mesoamerica
content:
**Tuesday, December 26, 2023**

On November 4, Russian Wikinews attended the exhibition titled "The Architectural Art of the Vanished Civilizations of Mesoamerica" by Russian photographer Viktor Pinchuk at the Central Museum of Taurida in Simferopol, Crimea. The event took place during the Night of the Arts, an annual cultural event in Russia, and was organized by a local chapter of the Russian Historical Society. Museum equipment facilitated the display of the artworks on a screen.

The event commenced with a speech by Elena Borisovna Vishnevskaya, a representative of the Central Museum of Taurida: 
"Having virtually walked a portion of the route of the solo Latin American expedition undertaken by the author of these photographs, we will briefly feel like travelers, immersed in the atmosphere of distant journeys, and sense the spirit of antiquity, as if we found ourselves among the noble but enigmatic Mayans, Aztecs, and Mixtecs—talented in architecture, stern in sacrifices, wise, and warrior-like."

Next, the creator of the photo collection addressed the audience:
"The multifaceted authorial project, whose cornerstone was the Latin American expedition—both the longest in duration and the most extensive in route—has yielded significant results: a book promoting global travel has been published, over twenty articles have been written for the Russian-language section of Wikipedia, and a virtual photo exhibition showcasing the ancient architecture of indigenous tribes was held."
